scenes.location: A MIDSUMMER DAWN. THORNFIELD THE GROUNDS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: First light. Jane Eyre is running across a meadow, flushe and breathless; the hem of her plain, black dress soaked with dew. She carries a shawl and has a small bag of belongings over her shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She trips, falls to her knees; looks back. Expressive eye open features. She is desperate. We see the house she is running from; a Jacobean battlemented mansion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Her need to escape is so great that she crawls forward until she is able to raise herself to her feet. She runs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She reaches an antique stile by a brook. She lifts hersel on to it. She lands on the road. And runs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sun is higher in the sky. Jane exhausted, now running down a main road. Her spirts lift at the sight of an approaching coach. She flags it down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane empties her purse into the driver's hand. He looks a her money then suspiciously back at her. A terse nod indicates she can get in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane sinks into a dark corner. Her fellow passengers look shocked by her dishevelled appearance at such an early hour. She undertakes a tremendous effort not to betray he emotional state. She doesn't sob, she doesn't howl - although her breathing threatens to. Slowly, unable to be the day, she closes her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sunset. A whitewashed, stone pillar set up where four roa meet on a barren moor. The coach driver opens the door. With a curt nod he indicates that Jane must get out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She looks around, dismayed. In each direction there is op moorland for as far as the eye can see. The driver sets o at a good pace - glad to be rid of such a passenger. Jane puts her hand to her side for her bag of belongings. It i not there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She runs as fast as she can after the coach. It is recedi towards the horizon. She comes to a halt, objectless, los alone. She pulls her knitted shawl around her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She leaves the road and sets off across the moor, into th gathering dark. Jane Eyre adapted by Moira Buffini March 2008 2.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane is on her knees by a strange overhanging rock. The night sky is awesome; the universe is all around her. She is trying to calm herself with a prayer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane lies on a great rock, soaking up the heat of the sun She is like someone numb with pain. She watches a lizard crawl over the rock. She is mesmerised.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane squats in the heather and eats bilberries as the lig fades. She hungrily licks the juice from her hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane is asleep in the heather, her shawl wrapped around her. A red-haired child in a white nightgown lies by her side, watching her. It is Helen Burns.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Helen reaches out. She touches Jane's hand. Jane wakes. S sits up. She is alone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane is crouched on a rock watching the waters go by. The sky is overcast. The first big drops of rain land on the stones. Jane makes no movement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A raven lands on a rock nearby. Jane is suddenly filled with a wild rage. She picks up a stone and hurls it at th bird with a raw cry. The gesture exhausts her. She watche the bird wheel away, as the rain starts to pour.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is raining hard. Jane sees a small girl come out of th farm with some leftovers. She drops them into a pigpen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane leaning into the pigpen. She picks a stiffened mould of porridge out of the mud. She lets the rain wash it. Sh eats it ravenously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It has stopped raining. Jane is huddled under a tree. She is shaking, shuddering. The life has gone out of her eyes Jane Eyre adapted by Moira Buffini March 2008 3.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The moors rise away above her to the horizon. Jane looks at the sun starting to set. The clouds are red and gold.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She sees a small red-haired girl in a white nightgown walking barefoot on the moors ahead of her. The girl turn looks back at Jane. With her last strength, Jane follows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dark clouds are banking up; the rain starts again. Jane i struggling through a marsh. Her boots are stuck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She falls. Her hand disappears into mud; her face pressed against the earth. She doesn't move. She has reached the point of despair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The girl's bare feet walk close by, as if waiting for her Jane looks up. Where the child should be, she sees a ligh shining across the moor. Jane starts crawling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane is toiling on through the lashing rain towards the light. It has become a window. A brief flash of lightning shows her a low stone cottage. Helen Burns is sitting on the gate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane is crawling through the narrow garden. On her knees, she peers through a window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On either side of a bright little fire sit two young wome They look exactly like Jane; slight, neat, dressed in black. One, Diana, has her hair slightly curled and hides her gentle eyes behind spectacles. The other, Mary, is ve young; no more than seventeen. Each has a book on her kne They are talking intimately.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They look so close, so loving and the room looks so cosy that it pains Jane considerably.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane knocking at the door. Hannah, an old servant answers She is suspicious; Jane looks like a wretch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you want?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane manages to find her voice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shelter. Jane Eyre adapted by Moira Buffini March 2008 4.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't take in vagrants. Here's a penny. Now take it and go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have no strength to go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can move off. And if there are others with you tell them we are not alone. We have a gentleman here, and dogs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I must die if I am turned away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The door slams shut. Jane lets out a hopeless wail.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: God help me. I will die.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She turns away, her hope gone. As she collapses, she find herself supported by a strong pair of black-clad arms.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All of God's creatures must die. But not prematurely - and not on my doorstep I hope.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane is lifted up. She finds herself looking into the fac of the handsomest man she has ever seen; St John Rivers. lifts her over the threshold into the warmth of Moor Hous

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A fire is roaring in the stove. Hannah is bent over it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We've had a beggar woman come, Mr Rivers. I sent her - For shame!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hannah falls silent as she sees Jane.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You did your duty in excluding her. Let me do mine in admitting her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He sets Jane down before the hearth. She can barely stand She is soaked to the bone, filthy with mud. Her skin has ghastly pallor. Diana and Mary enter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: St John, who is it? Jane Eyre adapted by Moira Buffini March 2008 5.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know; I found her at the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought her one of the gypsies from the cross.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's as white as death.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane can hold herself up no longer. Diana moves forward. She and St John catch Jane and help her into a chair. The rain hammers on the windows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hannah, some water.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's worn to nothing. She looks like a spectre. St John, if you hadn't taken her in, we would have fallen upon her dead body in the morning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's no vagrant; I'm sure of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's milk and bread for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane tries to mouth her thanks. She sips the milk. Eats a mouthful of bread. Diana kneels at her side.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ask her her name.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I - I am J -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane cannot speak. She's incapable of uttering her own name. She hears John Reed's voice calling from far away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane Eyre!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please, tell us how we may help you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can we send for anyone? Who are your people? Jane Eyre adapted by Moira Buffini March 2008 6.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The questions are deeply troubling to Jane. She is losing consciousness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She sees an image of a small girl of ten, running away through a great darkening room. Jane tries to follow her. The action draws her up out of the kitchen chair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She hears John Reed's voice again.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN REED, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Jane Eyre! Where are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane, panicked, looking for somewhere to hide, passes out

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rain hammers against the windows. Jane aged ten, looking hunted, runs in looking for somewhere to hide.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She springs behind a curtain. John Reed enters; a fourtee year old, his stomach bursting out of his fancy clothes. is holding a riding crop as if it is a sword.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come out, rat. I know you are in here. Come out now and I won't punish you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane watches him pass by her. He practises a perfect lung

dialogues.speaker: JOHN REED, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Rat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He exits. Jane breathes a sigh of relief. She slowly pull the curtain across, making the window a private sanctuary There is a book lying on the seat. She opens it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane is sitting cross-legged, completely absorbed in her book - a beautifully drawn picture of a cormorant. She ru her finger over it. We hear the sound of great waves plunging on to a shore.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane, aged ten, is sitting cross-legged on an isolated rock, her eyes locked with those of a stooping black cormorant. St John's voice comes from a long way away.

dialogues.speaker: ST JOHN, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Diana, Mary help me get her upstairs...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The cormorant raises its wings like a great black cloak. Jane watches as it takes off and flies away. Jane Eyre adapted by Moira Buffini March 2008 7.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane has her eyes closed. A great Atlantic wave hits the sash window behind her, drenching it with foam and brine. Suddenly the curtain is pulled back. John Reed stands in front of her. Jane shrinks back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have been looking for you these last ten minutes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you want?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Say forgive me, Master Reed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have done nothing wrong. Master Reed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John grabs the book.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who gave you permission to read my book?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wasn't aware it was yours.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everything in this house is mine. You're lucky to live here with gentleman's children like us. Your father had nothing. You should go and beg.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane stares him out. John can sense her contempt. He belt her with the book. Jane hits her head on the window clasp drawing blood. She is shocked.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN REED, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: That's for the look you had on your face. You bad animal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane snaps. She throws herself upon him, the rage in her released; pummelling, scratching, hurting him in any way she can. She is barely coherent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wicked and cruel - you are a slaver - a murderer -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I shall tell mother -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hate you John Reed. I hate you - Jane Eyre adapted by Moira Buffini March 2008 8.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John is flabbergasted. Like all bullies, he is terrified.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mamma! Mamma! There's a rat! Rat!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane bites him. Hard. At that moment, Mrs Reed appears on the scene. John screams. We see Mrs Reed's shocked face. She is an overweight woman pushing forty in a bright, elaborate dress.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dinah and Mary are gently taking Jane's soaking clothes off; one at each side of her. Jane is distressed, approaching a delirium. She resists them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane is carried in and set down on a footstool by two servants, Miss Abbot and Bessie - one at each side of her She is still resisting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For shame, hitting your master.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you don't sit still you must be tied down!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The fight goes out of Jane. She sits, defeated. Bessie, young and plump, quickly wipes her bleeding forehead. She has some compassion. Miss Abbot has none.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What we do is for your own good. If you are passionate and rude like this, your Aunt Reed will send you away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're worse than us servants. We work for our keep; you do nothing. Pray for forgiveness Miss Eyre or something bad will come down that chimney and fetch you away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The door slams. They are gone. Jane slowly grips the edge of the stool. The room is chill, silent. Red walls and curtains, murky in the fading light.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In front of Jane, a stone fireplace gapes like a mouth. Beside it, a full length looking-glass in which her pale reflection stares out. Behind her, a bed supported on pillars of mahogany, hung with red. Jane Eyre adapted by Moira Buffini March 2008 9.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The piled up pillows and mattresses glare in cold white. Jane's breathing is the only sound in the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A sudden gust sends rain pelting against the windows like fingernails. A distant moan of wind seems to breathe out the black hearth. Jane reverts her nervous gaze to the pitted mirror. Her eyes lock on the small figure trapped the mirror's visionary hollow; her white, bleeding face, her eyes glittering with fear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is a phantom. The eyes are black, the skin a deathly grey. Blood. Jane's breathing becomes choked with terror. She can't get her breath. We hear blood rushing through h ears. It sounds like the beating of great wings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Slowly, a light appears over her. It may be something shining in from outside. But to Jane it seems as if it is surrounding her, enveloping her. The figure in the lookin glass opens its mouth. The scream, held in so long, final rips from Jane's throat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At the sound of the scream, Mrs Reed, slumbering, almost jumps out of her skin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miss Abbott almost drops the tea tray she is carrying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane is banging on the door, screaming, hysterical with terror. Bessie rushes to the door and unlocks it. Jane flies into her arms.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miss Eyre what is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bessie!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you seen something?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There was a light.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see Bessie's own fear as she glances into the dark roo Mrs Reed is storming towards them, furious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bessie, I gave orders that she was to be left in the red room until I came. Jane Eyre adapted by Moira Buffini March 2008 10.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But she screamed so loud ma'am.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is play-acting. Let her go. I know your tricks Jane Eyre and I abhor such artifice. Loose Bessie's hands, child.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs Reed prises Jane away from Bessie as she speaks.

dialogues.speaker: MRS REED, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You will now stay here an hour longer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No - Aunt, have pity -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And only when you are perfectly submissive will I let you out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please - I cannot bear it -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Silence. This violence is repulsive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I shall be killed -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get back!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have mercy, have mercy I beg you -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs Reed throws her back into the room, slams the door an turns the key. We hear Jane's unspeakable howls of terror her anguished bangs upon the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bessie is looking at Mrs Reed aghast. Mrs Reed withers he with a frozen glare.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see Jane in her distress, hitting her head on the door She falls back. On the floor, her arms and legs move beyo her control. She is having a fit. When it is over, we see Jane unconscious. She is lying in a pool of ghostly light

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Through the light, Jane sees Mary and Diana Rivers at her side. Jane Eyre adapted by Moira Buffini March 2008 11.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's awake.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: St John approaches in his parson's collar, blocking out t light as he looks down. Jane gazes at him remotely.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sure we'll find she's simply had a misunderstanding with her people. I hope she's not done anything deplorable; there's nothing so sad as a fallen young woman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look at the suffering in her eyes. They're like dark pools -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Diana smiles at Mary's tendency to over-dramatise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She has a peculiar face; I rather like it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's not at all handsome.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's so ill, St John.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ill or well, she'll always be plain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane's eyes slide away from him and close.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A bright morning. A huge clergyman dressed in black is staring down at Jane, blocking out the sun. We see him fr her POV; his expansive chest, dramatic facial hair, huge flared nostrils, frowning brows. He is Brockelhurst, the epitome of grim.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is no sight so sad and so deplorable as that of a wicked little girl. Do you know, Jane Eyre, where the wicked go after death?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They go to hell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And what is hell, can you tell me that? Jane Eyre adapted by Moira Buffini March 2008 12.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A pit full of fire.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And should you like to fall into that pit and be burning there forever?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What must you do to avoid it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I must keep in good health and not die.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs Reed is by the fireside in an ultra-feminine dress. S puts down her tea cup in irritation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've been her sole benefactress and her kindest friend. But she shows no gratitude and brings nothing but discord into my house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is her parentage?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's an orphan. Her mother was my late husband's sister. On his deathbed he exhorted me to care for her. I have always treated her as one of my own.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane silently revolts against this lie.

dialogues.speaker: MRS REED, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: If you accept her at Lowood school Mr Brocklehurst, keep a strict eye on her. Her worst fault is a tendency to deceit. I'm sorry to tell you that Jane Eyre is a liar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane's eyes flash with outrage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All liars will have their portion in the lake burning with fire and brimstone. She shall be watched, Mrs Reed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wish her to be made useful, to be kept humble. Jane Eyre adapted by Moira Buffini March 2008 13.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can rest assured dear lady that we mortify our girls in the sentiments of vanity and pride. They are taught to be quiet, plain and modest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A passion of resentment is forming in Jane.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We shall root out the wickedness in this small, ungrateful plant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs Reed smiles sweetly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And as for its vacations, it must spend them all at Lowood.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane is climbing the staircase. John Reed blocks her way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, Rat, you're being sent away. It's as I thought; you're not fit to associate with me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane snaps. She cries out:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You are not fit to associate with me!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs Reed is at her desk. Jane appears in front of her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You said I was a liar. Well I am not. If I was, I should say that I loved you and I don't. I dislike you the worst of anybody in the world except John Reed. He is a liar, not I.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How dare you speak in this manner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll never call you Aunt again as long as I live and if anyone asks how I liked you I'll say that the very thought of you makes me sick. Jane Eyre adapted by Moira Buffini March 2008 14.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You wouldn't dare.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll remember how you thrust me back into the Red Room and locked me there to my dying day. Even when you knew it was haunted and I begged to be let out. People think you are good but you are bad and hard-hearted and I'll let everyone at Lowood know what you have done!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Children must be corrected for their faults.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Deceit is not my fault!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you are passionate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My Uncle Reed is in heaven and can see all that you do and think; so can my mother and father. They know how you hate me and wish me dead. They can see. They see everything you do and they will judge you, Mrs Reed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs Reed has turned quite pale. Jane blazes with victory.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bessie is waiting with Jane while her belongings are load onto a public coach, its top laden with passengers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're such a queer, solitary little thing. If only you could make yourself more appealing. Perhaps if you tried smiling from time to time, people would find you more pleasant -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't scold me Bessie. I know you dislike me -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't dislike you Miss; I'm fonder of you than of anyone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't show it. Jane Eyre adapted by Moira Buffini March 2008 15.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miss Jane -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane throws her arms around Bessie and embraces her with great force. Bessie returns the embrace, surprised, moved Jane gets into the coach. Bessie looks up at the driver.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You take good care of her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane's small, pale face peers out of the coach window, watching Gateshead recede. She doesn't cry. But Bessie can't stave off her tears.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane, half asleep is carried out of a coach and into a howling gale. She is taken under a stone inscription: `Lowood Institution'. She is set down in front of a woman with striking features and intelligent eyes; Miss Temple. She bends down and looks into Jane's face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's your name, child?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane Eyre.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You are very young to be sent alone, Jane Eyre.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She gently touches Jane's cheek with her finger. Jane manages the ghost of a smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane is lying back against clean white pillows. Her hair brushed and neatly plaited. Diana and Mary are full of kindness but St John's face is cold, dispassionate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My name is Jane Elliott...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane Elliot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where do you come from, Miss Elliott?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane gives no answer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who can we send for to help you? Jane Eyre adapted by Moira Buffini March 2008 16.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is an intake of breath from Mary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you mean to say that you are absolutely without home and without friends?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How did you come to be roaming the moors, Miss Elliott?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't upset her, St John. She must not be interrogated so.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr Rivers, you and you sisters have done me a great service, the greatest man can do - you have rescued me from death.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How are we to help you if we know nothing about you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll tell you as much as I can. I am an orphan; brought up a dependent; educated in a charity school where I passed six years as a pupil and two as a teacher. I left a year since to become a private governess -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A good situation, where I remained until...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Diana, didn't I say so? Didn't I say she was a governess?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We did wonder. We mean no offence but you have a certain look. Mary and I work as governesses too. Jane Eyre adapted by Moira Buffini March 2008 17.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with great interest) Do you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We are currently trying to teach ourselves German, so we may find better positions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're not working at present?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We came home only for our father's funeral.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He died three weeks ago.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am very sorry to hear it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: St John has no patience with the change of subject.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why did you leave your place of employment?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane sinks back in the pillows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I... It was a catastrophe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What did you do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am free from any blame, sir. I was happy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane is deeply distressed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's enough for now, St John.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You must rest, Miss Elliott.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The name sounds strange to Jane.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why did you start?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because that is not my name. Jane Eyre adapted by Moira Buffini March 2008 18.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You haven't given us your real name?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane shakes her head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why not?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because I must not ever be found.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Diana and Mary glance at each other, fascinated.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane is dressing herself. She stops, weakly holding the back of a chair for support, looking out of the window at the sun setting over the hills.

dialogues.speaker: ST JOHN, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Merciful Jesus, enlighten thou me with the brightness of thine inward light...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Diana is helping Jane down the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: ST JOHN, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: And take away all darkness from the habitation of my heart...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: St John is praying over Jane, Diana and Mary as they sit the table. Mary catches Jane's eye, gives her shy smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Join me to thyself with an inseparable band of love... For thou, even thou alone, dost satisfy him that loveth thee...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane finds herself staring at St John, who prays ardently

dialogues.speaker: ST JOHN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And without thee all things are vain and empty. Amen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: St John opens his eyes and looks searchingly at Jane. She immediately looks down.

dialogues.speaker: JANE, MARY, DIANA
dialogues.text: Amen. Jane Eyre adapted by Moira Buffini March 2008 19.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Welcome to our table, Miss Elliott.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd appreciate it if you called me Jane. It is my own name.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's wonderful to see you on your feet, Miss Jane.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane turns her attention to St John.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I trust I will not be eating long at your expense, Mr Rivers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You wish to be independent of my charity?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wish to work, sir. Show me how to work or how to seek work; that's all I ask.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're not fit enough to work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My sisters have always taken pleasure in keeping injured birds but I'm more inclined to put you in a way of keeping yourself - and shall endeavour to do so, if that's what you wish.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With all my heart, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a shame she has no choice of helpers, St John, and must put up with such crusty people as you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This school you were at, Miss Elliot, this charitable institution; what did it prepare you for?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see a bundle of sharp twigs come down on a girl's bare neck, like a whip.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane Eyre adapted by Moira Buffini March 2008 20.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane flinches at the memory.

dialogues.speaker: ST JOHN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Was it a thorough education?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Most thorough.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miss Scatcherd's bitter life is in her face and voice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Burns, Helen Burns!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane, aged ten, looks up. She is wearing a brown stuff frock with a puritanical cap like all the other girls. Silence reigns in the school hall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A red haired girl of about thirteen stands up; Helen Burn Miss Scatcherd holds up an apron in which a hole has been mistakenly cut.

dialogues.speaker: MISS SCATCHERD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You're a slattern and a disgrace!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Helen Burns undoes the back of her dress. The punishment given; a dozen sharp, stinging whacks with the birch twig

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane is appalled. But to her astonishment and awe, Helen Burns doesn't cry; she barely changes her expression. As the strokes go on - seven, eight, nine - Helen seems like one in a trance. Jane is deeply affected.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On the eleventh stroke, the door bursts open and a visiti party walks in: the Brocklehurst family. Miss Temple escorts two young girls dressed in peacock finery and two smart, bombastic ladies. Mr Brocklehurst follows. Helen's punishment is forgotten as the students rush to their fee

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane, in a panic, drops her slate and breaks it. Brocklehurst's eyes sweep the room. They land on her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I might have known. The new girl. Step forward, Jane Eyre.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Filled with dread, Jane steps forward.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is my duty dear children, to warn you that this girl is not one of God's own lambs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see the look of frustration on Miss Temple's face. Jane Eyre adapted by Moira Buffini March 2008 21.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She is a castaway and an alien in his flock and you must be on your guard against her. For this child... is a liar!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He points to a tall stool. Jane stands on it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is the pedestal of infamy - and you'll remain upon it all day. You'll receive no sustenance and no comfort, for you must learn how barren is the life of the sinner. Children, I exhort you to shun her, exclude her, shut her out from this day forth. Withhold the hand of friendship and deny your love to Jane Eyre, the liar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The hall is empty but for the small figure of Jane, high her stool, feeling her isolation like pain. Across the ro is the slightly bigger figure of Helen, hunched, the back of her dress still open, the skin on her neck raw. The su is setting. At last Jane starts to sob.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come now, don't cry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're not allowed to speak to me. I must be shunned.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr Brocklehurst is not a God. He's not liked or admired here -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He said I was a liar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am not a liar!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If your own conscience approves you, then so will I.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane is deeply gratified.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do you bear it? Jane Eyre adapted by Moira Buffini March 2008 22.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bear what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Being struck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm a trial to Miss Scatcherd. She hits me to improve me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If she hit me I would get that birch from her hand and break it under her nose.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'd just be punished even more. It's part of life here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have always been excluded and alone and hated. Miss Abbott used to call me an ugly little toad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Helen approaches Jane.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're not ugly. Do you know what is inside you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The spark of your spirit, the principle of light and thought, pure and bright, as perfect as anything created.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your soul. Your soul is beautiful, your soul has value - more value than anything on earth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that true?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. God sees your beauty. Even as you stand on that stool, there is an invisible world around you, a kingdom of spirits. It is everywhere. Angels see your pain. Angels know your innocence. Jane Eyre adapted by Moira Buffini March 2008 23.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Angels?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Helen smiles a wide smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you not believe in angels?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They hear the door. Helen runs back to her place; cowers. Miss Temple appears in a shaft of light at the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come here, Girls.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The girls approach, dreading more punishment.

dialogues.speaker: MISS TEMPLE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I shall investigate Mr Brocklehurst's claims against you, Jane. And unless they are proved, you will be exonerated.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miss Temple looks over her shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: MISS TEMPLE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Also, I understand you girls have had no food today.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She quickly presses a slice of hard cake into each girl's hand and walks away. Jane and Helen look at one another, deeply moved by her kindness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane stands between Diana and Mary high above Moor House. They are dressed similarly in bonnets and cloaks. They watch a hawk dive, their heads moving in unison. Their ey land upon Moor House.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We've lived here all our lives but the house must be shut up now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We can't afford to keep it on. Diana and I will return to our charges in a few days and St John will go to his parsonage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Down below them, St John leaves Moor House and walks towards the village. Jane watches him. Jane Eyre adapted by Moira Buffini March 2008 24.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It'll be a hard parting for us. We may not see him again for years.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why ever not?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He means to be a missionary. He's going to India to do Gods's work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can he not do God's work here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This quiet parish will never do for him; he almost raves in his restlessness. It breaks our hearts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: St John burns with talents and ambition. But he lacks the means for advancement here. Our poverty thwarts him at every turn and so he has chosen to lay all his gifts on God's altar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We've tried to persuade him to stay but in some things our brother is - he is -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Inexorable as death.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We are now without father. We'll soon be without home and brother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane feels a powerful compassion for them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In one thing you are fortunate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She looks over at the horizon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have each other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane is looking at the high wall which is the horizon of her world at Lowood. Her eyes come to rest on the main door. Two men are carrying a small coffin out of the school. Brocklehurst follows it with a menthol-soaked clo over his mouth and nose. He becomes aware of Jane's eyes him. He looks away. Jane Eyre adapted by Moira Buffini March 2008 25.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane is creeping down a corridor in her night dress. She peers in through the dormitory door. It has been turned into a sanitarium. Camphor and vinegar are being burnt. Jane can hardly look at the sick girls.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miss Temple, pale with exhaustion, is speaking intimately to Madame Pierrot, the French mistress. Jane overhears.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is the result of semi- starvation and neglected colds; Brockelhurst's idea of mortifying their bodies to save their souls.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miss Temple can't say more.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Write to the governors. You must.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane creeps on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane opens the door. A small bed has been set up at the foot of Miss Temple's. In it lies Helen Burns. A candle i set on a table at her side. Jane takes her hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Helen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is it you, Jane? Have you come to say goodbye?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're cold.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm very happy. I am going home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Back to your father?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My father has a new wife. He'll not miss me much.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then where?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To my future home, where all is light. I am going to God. Jane Eyre adapted by Moira Buffini March 2008 26.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane is devastated. She climbs into bed next to Helen. Fo a moment, they hold each other. Jane's tears silently fal

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't be sad. I will escape great suffering by dying young.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't have any talent to make my way in life. I should be always at fault. But God is my friend. He loves me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then he must save you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is saving me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane cannot articulate her distress at Helen's words.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I feel like I could sleep now. I like to have you near -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I won't leave you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're so warm and alive. Jane, you have a passion for living.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see Miss Temple looking down at the bed in the dazzlin morning light. Jane, waking, has her small arms around Helen, as if fiercely protecting her. Helen is ashen, her eyes open, staring at some unseen thing. She is dead. Mis Temple lifts Jane away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane realises what has happened. We hear the sound of her distress begin. She is inconsolable.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, no, no -

dialogues.speaker: MARY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Jane? Jane Eyre adapted by Moira Buffini March 2008 27.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane is staring out at the Autumn rain. She surreptitious wipes her tears away and smiles up at Mary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you something for me to do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You are doing something already. May I see?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane hands her a book. She has drawn a bride.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's Miss Temple on her wedding day. She was my teacher; a great influence on me. Under her guidance I became a teacher too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary turns the page. It shows a sketch of St John Rivers. Mary gasps in delight. She takes the book straight to St John, who is diligently working at his desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: St John -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, Mary, please -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See how skilled Jane is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: St John looks at the sketch of himself. He is quite taken aback. He looks over at Jane, who is quite embarrassed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She is better than any drawing master we have ever had.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For a moment, St John seems to be weighing up whether to insulted or not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How fierce I am, Miss Elliott.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr Rivers, I wondered if you had yet heard of any work that I could do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I found you a situation some days ago but I've delayed telling you because the work is lowly and I fear you'll scorn it. Jane Eyre adapted by Moira Buffini March 2008 28.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I shan't mind what I do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As I am poor and obscure, the help I can offer is of the meanest sort.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: St John, what are you going to offer her? Not washerwoman, I hope?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When I took over the parish two years ago it had no school. I opened one for boys; I now intend to open one for girls. The school mistress will have a two-roomed cottage paid for by local benefactors and she will receive fifteen pounds a year. You can see how humble, how ignoble it is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On the contrary, Jane is deeply gratified.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr Rivers, I thank you heartily and I accept with all my heart.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you comprehend me? It's a village school - cottagers daughters. What will you do with all your fine accomplishments?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I will save them until they are wanted. They will keep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane smiles at him. St John is impressed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane is at the blackboard in a freshly painted school roo In front of her are about twenty village girls, aged from six to sixteen. They are hanging on her every word.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane is writing a neat line of 'a's.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane's first home is like a doll's house. She walks throu it from the whitewashed bedroom with its little single be through the parlour with its tiny fireplace into the scullery kitchen. She retraces her steps back into the parlour. She turns round and surveys it. Jane Eyre adapted by Moira Buffini March 2008 29.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Silence but for the crackling of the fire and the blowing of the wind. She feels glad, grateful, but very, very alone. She hears Brocklehurst's voice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hear you are to leave us, Miss Eyre.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She spins around as if he is there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brocklehurst is at the church door; Jane looking at him coldly. She holds a bunch of wild flowers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. Excuse me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She walks into the graveyard. There are over forty small graves marked with wooden crosses, each bearing a child's name. One of them says Helen Burns. Jane lays down her flowers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She looks up at Brocklehurst. He cannot meet her eye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We hear the voice of Mrs Fairfax.

dialogues.speaker: MRS FAIRFAX, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: If Jane Eyre of Lowood School...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane tries to quell her great unhappiness. She springs in action, straightening her furniture, stoking her fire.

dialogues.speaker: MRS FAIRFAX, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: ...Who advertised in the Yorkshire Herald, possesses the acquirements mentioned...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane, younger and more hopeful, with her belongings in a small trunk, awaits an approaching public coach.

dialogues.speaker: MRS FAIRFAX, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: ...And if she is in a position to give satisfactory references, a situation can be offered where there is but one pupil, a little girl under ten years of age and where the salary is thirty pounds a year. Jane Eyre adapted by Moira Buffini March 2008 30.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane is in her scullery putting all her energy into scrubbing dishes.

dialogues.speaker: MRS FAIRFAX, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Jane Eyre is requested to send references and all particulars to Mrs Fairfax at Thornfield Hall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane closes her eyes, trying to banish her thoughts. It i no good. The memories crowd in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A smiling lady dressed in black approaches her through th darkness - Mrs Alice Fairfax.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do you do, my dear? What a long and tedious journey you must have had of it. John is quite the slowest driver in the county. You must be cold to the bone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you Mrs Fairfax?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Indeed I am; come and warm yourself in here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs Fairfax leads Jane up the dark corridor and into a co parlour. Leah, a young maidservant, follows.

dialogues.speaker: MRS FAIRFAX, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Your poor hands must be quite numb; here, let me help you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs Fairfax undoes the ribbon on Jane's bonnet. Jane is taken aback, unused to motherliness of any kind.

dialogues.speaker: MRS FAIRFAX, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Leah, make a little hot port and cut a sandwich or two.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leah eyes Jane with great curiosity. She hurries away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Draw nearer the fire. John is taking your trunk up to your room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Knitting apparatus lies abandoned on a fireside chair. Mr Fairfax moves it and gestures for Jane to sit. Jane Eyre adapted by Moira Buffini March 2008 31.

dialogues.speaker: MRS FAIRFAX, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I've put you at the back of the house; I hope you don't mind. The rooms at the front have much finer furniture but they are so gloomy and solitary I think.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane can't help noticing that every surface is covered in lace, embroidery, or fine crochet. The whole room is an advertisement for Mrs Fairfax's skill at handicrafts - an testament to the hours she has spent alone.

dialogues.speaker: MRS FAIRFAX, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I'm so glad you are come. To be sure this is a fine old house but I must confess that in winter one can feel a little dreary and alone. Leah is a very nice girl and John and Martha good people too, but they are servants - and one cannot talk to them on terms of equality.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Am I to have the pleasure of meeting Miss Fairfax tonight?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miss Fairfax - my pupil?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh you mean Miss Varens; Mr Rochester's ward. She is to be your pupil.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who is Mr Rochester?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why, the owner of Thornfield.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought Thornfield Hall belonged to you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (bursting into laughter) Oh bless you child, what an idea. To me? I am only the housekeeper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forgive me - Jane Eyre adapted by Moira Buffini March 2008 32.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a distant connection between Mr Rochester and I - his mother was a Fairfax - but I'd never presume on it. Heavens, me, owner of Thornfield?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She continues to laugh. A bashful smile is playing on Jane's lips. Mrs Fairfax is beginning to thaw her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs Fairfax is carrying a lamp across the great hall; the only light. Jane can perceive grandeur looming out of the darkness; Jacobean fireplace, coat of arms, head of a sta Very gloomy, eerie. Her breath is vaporising in the cold.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We shall have a cheerful house this winter...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Jane follows Mrs Fairfax up the stairs, light is throw on portraits of dour, craggy, long dead ancestors.

dialogues.speaker: MRS FAIRFAX, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: With Miss Varens here - and with you - we'll have quite a merry time of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dark heavy drapes, another striking portrait. A dark, voluptuous woman in an 18th Century gown, ruby lipped, on full breast exposed. Jane glances away, taken aback by th woman's bold expression and her nakedness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sure that last winter - and what a severe one - if it didn't rain it snowed and if it didn't snow it blew a gale - last winter I declare that not a soul came to the house from November to February.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs Fairfax leads Jane through the wood-panelled darkness

dialogues.speaker: MRS FAIRFAX, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I got quite melancholy night after night alone. When spring finally came I thought it a great relief that I hadn't gone distracted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She opens the door to a small but delightful room. Jane Eyre adapted by Moira Buffini March 2008 33.

dialogues.speaker: MRS FAIRFAX, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane looks in: a fire burning, a lamp lit by her bed, a soft quilt, pale chintz curtains.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She is utterly speechless. Her eight years of physical discomfort and hardship are over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good night, my dear. I hope you'll be comfy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs Fairfax can see how affected she is - and how hard sh is trying to button it down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane opens the curtains. She draws her breath in at the sight of the grounds. They are beautiful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane enters a magnificent room. Mrs Fairfax is dusting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What a beautiful house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr Rochester's visits here are always unexpected. He doesn't like to arrive and find everything all swathed up, so I keep it in constant readiness. Now, come and meet Miss Varens. Did I mention she was French?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Adele Varens, an exquisitely dressed child of eight, is chatting animatedly to Jane and Mrs Fairfax. At her side Sophie, her nurse - a desperately shy and lonely girl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sophie has been crying because no one understands. Nobody can speak to us except for Mr Rochester and he has gone away. Jane Eyre adapted by Moira Buffini March 2008 34.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would you ask her about her parents? Mr Rochester's neglected to tell me anything about her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where did you live Adele, before you came to Thornfield?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With Maman - but she is gone to the Holy Virgin now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Her mother has passed away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maman used to teach me to dance and say verses. When gentlemen came to see her I used to dance for them or sit on their knees and sing. May I sing for you now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well - that would be lovely. (To Mrs Fairfax) Adele is going to show us her accomplishments.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Adele adopts a lovelorn pose. She sings an operetta song; forsaken lady plotting vengeance on her lover. Her high voice warbles with pretended emotion. The effect is rathe weird. Jane and Mrs Fairfax watch, open-mouthed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How very French...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Adele's song continues as a voiceover. Mrs Fairfax is finishing a shawl. Jane is showing Adele pictures of litt objects that she has sketched. Adele names them in Englis

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The song ends. Jane gives Adele a sketch of herself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Me! It is me!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs Fairfax shakes out the finished shawl and puts it rou Jane's shoulders, departing before Jane can protest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here. For you. Jane Eyre adapted by Moira Buffini March 2008 35.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane is delighted at the kindness of the gift.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane holds a candle, the shawl around her; the moaning sound of a gale outside. She holds her candle up to the portrait of the voluptuous woman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She stares at it curious, both as a girl and as an artist She brings the candle close, to see how the brushwork has achieved the effect of flesh. She hears a low, knowing laugh in the darkness behind her. She is startled.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who's there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Her own huge shadow is the only thing that moves. She hea the laugh again. She follows it through the darkness, ale with fear. A door clicks shut at the end of the corridor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To her relief Jane sees Mrs Fairfax approach with a lamp.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who sleeps up here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No one. This part of the house is quite empty, except for you and me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I heard someone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can't have done.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A laugh. Someone laughed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs Fairfax flounders for a second.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh - that must be Grace Poole. She likes to sit up here with her sewing. Rather an eccentric soul. (She shouts sharply) Grace? Grace!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A door opens. Jane sees a broad-faced woman with slow, intelligent eyes. She looks as if she has just woken up.

dialogues.speaker: MRS FAIRFAX, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Miss Eyre has heard a laugh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grace looks at Jane with sly curiosity. She leaves the sewing room and opens a door through which a flight of steep steps are revealed. Grace climbs them and disappear Jane Eyre adapted by Moira Buffini March 2008 36.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane is on the turreted roof, looking up at the cawing rooks - and down at the view; a white, frosted wilderness

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane senses a presence behind her. She quickly turns. Mrs Fairfax is coming through the rooftop door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought I might find you up here. I've been waiting to pour our tea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not in need of tea, thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs Fairfax approaches, concerned.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is it, child? You've been here three months now and I'm worried that the position is not enough / to occupy your -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, Mrs Fairfax, no. I'm so thankful to be at Thornfield. Please don't think I'm so ungrateful as to be discontented.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But it's a quiet life, isn't it? This isolated house; a still doom for a young woman...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane looks out at the view once more.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wish a woman could have action in her life, like a man. It agitates me to pain that the sky- line over there is ever our limit. I long sometimes for a power of vision that would overpass it. If I could behold all I imagine... I've never seen a city, never spoken with men. I've never even seen a town of any size. And I fear my whole life will pass, without ever having...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs Fairfax's troubled look makes Jane fall silent. Mrs Fairfax looks as if she is about to say something - then puts on her practical face, the moment of intimacy gone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well now - exercise is a great cure for anything, they say.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane Eyre adapted by Moira Buffini March 2008 37.

dialogues.speaker: MRS FAIRFAX, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I have some letters to post; will you take them?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane is walking with purpose, carrying a bundle of letter The exercise is lifting her spirits. The sun is sinking, turning the frost gold.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A brook runs close to the path; half frozen. Its slow trickle is the only sound to be heard. Jane moves slowly, acutely aware of everything around her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Further into the wood, the brook has frozen right across the path. Jane slips on it as she passes. The noise of he feet echoes. She steadies herself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She gazes at a huddle of snowdrops, their heads bowed. A crystal drop of water runs to the end of a snowdrop and begins to freeze as she watches. It is held suspended as the whole winter is contained in it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The moon is mounting the sky. Jane hears a sound like the beating of wings. The blood is rushing through her ears.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Her trance is broken by the figure of a great dog - which glides past her so close it almost knocks her off her fee The beating is loud; not wings she realises, but the rush of an approaching horse. It is almost on top of her befor she can move. Her shocked, pale face, her black garments startle both horse and rider.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the deuce -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The rider gets the horse under control and continues, onl to have his horse slip on the ice. Both man and horse fal with a crash. The dog begins to bark, until the hills ech with the sound. The horse is on one side; the man is lyin trapped beneath it on the ice; Edward Fairfax Rochester.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hellfire.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane is confounded.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pilot, get down! GET DOWN I SAY!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I do anything, sir?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rochester stares at her; a tiny black figure, surrounded darkening frost, the low moon behind her. Jane Eyre adapted by Moira Buffini March 2008 38.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane doesn't move. Rochester turns to his horse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mesrour. Mesrour.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With much stamping and clattering, the horse clambers to its feet. Rochester seems relieved.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He tries to stand himself. His ankle will bear no weight. He lets out an involuntary cry. It echoes:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Damnation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you injured, sir?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rochester looks at her once more. He manages to get himse off the ice. He sits on a nearby stile. Jane approaches him. She now has the moon on her face. She begins to look less like a phantom and more like a girl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you are hurt and want help I can fetch someone from the village. I'm on my way there to post a letter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rochester looks as if he doesn't believe her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where do you come from?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thornfield Hall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whose house is that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr Rochester's.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you know Mr Rochester?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I've never seen him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rochester is trying to place her. She is a puzzle to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're not a servant there...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am the governess, sir. Jane Eyre adapted by Moira Buffini March 2008 39.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The governess. (A slow smile) Deuce take me, I had forgotten.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Examining Jane once more, he laughs a low laugh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The governess.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane does not like to be laughed at.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you got an umbrella I can use as a stick?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then try to get hold of his bridle and lead him to me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane doesn't like his imperious tone. She looks at the horse; huge, trampling, nervous. Rochester is amused.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you would be so kind...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane obeys. She endeavours to catch the bridle but the horse rears away. Jane falls on the ice. Rochester bursts out laughing. Jane picks herself up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perhaps it would be easier to bring me to the horse. Come here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane resists.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forgive me. I must beg of you to come here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane approaches. Rochester instantly leans all his weight on her. She almost crumples under it; the first time she has ever touched and been touched by a man. She holds him up. And walks him closer to his horse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mesrour.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The horse approaches him. Rochester calms it. He springs into the saddle, grimacing as he wrenches his sprain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you. (He bows.) Now, make haste with your letter. Jane Eyre adapted by Moira Buffini March 2008 40.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rochester's spurred heel makes the horse start and rear. Jane steps back. The horse bounds away, the dog rushing i its traces. All three disappear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane doesn't move until the sound of hooves has faded awa Her face is flushed, her eyes glitter in the dark.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane runs up to the front door. She pushes it open. To he amazement, there is a fire burning in the stone fireplace The whole hall is lit. The double doors are open into the library. Mrs Fairfax is hurriedly approaching.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr Rochester is here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go and change your frock; he wishes to meet you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have to change?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh yes - I always dress for the evening when Mr Rochester is here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But all my dresses are the same.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You must have one that is better? He's in a terrible humour; the doctor has been. His horse fell in Hay lane and his ankle is sprained.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs Fairfax anxiously hurries back into the library. A large dog wanders out. Jane finds herself looking at Pilo She smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane enters. Rochester is in front of a superb fire - one foot bandaged and supported on a stool. Pilot is at his feet - and so is Adele, gazing adoringly at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rochester is looking through Jane's portfolio of sketches and watercolours. Jane feels utterly exposed - as if her diary is being read. Mrs Fairfax timidly interrupts. Jane Eyre adapted by Moira Buffini March 2008 41.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here is Miss Eyre, Sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Without looking up) Let her sit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane sits. Rochester continues to study her work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have examined Adele and I find you've taken great pains with her. She's not bright, she has no talents - yet in a short time she's made much improvement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Adele is gazing at him uncomprehending, her face radiant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've been resident here three months?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And from whence do you hail; what's your tale of woe?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pardon?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All governesses have a tale of woe; what's yours?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was brought up by my Aunt, Mrs Reed of Gateshead, in a house far finer than this. At ten years old I went to Lowood school where I received as good an education as I could hope for. I have no tale of woe, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where are your parents?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you remember them? Jane Eyre adapted by Moira Buffini March 2008 42.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And why are you not with Mrs Reed of Gateshead now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She cast me off, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because I was burdensome and she disliked me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lowood; that's a charity school, isn't it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How long did you survive there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eight years.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No tale of woe...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I daily thank providence for sending us Miss Eyre. She's a kind and patient teacher and an invaluable / companion -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't trouble yourself to give her a character. I'll judge for myself. She began by felling my horse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have her to thank for this sprain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs Fairfax looks at Jane, bewildered. Rochester lifts on of her watercolours.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Adele has brought me these; are they yours? Jane Eyre adapted by Moira Buffini March 2008 43.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A swollen sea. A cormorant, a golden bracelet held in its beak. A girl's arm coming out of the water, white and deathly, her drowned figure underneath.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where did you get your copies?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Out of my head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That head I now see on your shoulders?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turns the next. The top of a hill. An expanse of twilight sky. Rising up, a girl's shape, her forehead crowned with a star, red hair flowing; Helen Burns.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who's this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The evening star.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rochester gives her a direct gaze.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why did you bewitch my horse?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane cannot reply.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane is by the blackboard, where she is writing sums.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tonight I will have my cadeaux. He always bring me a cadeaux.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs Fairfax breathlessly enters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry to disturb. He's asked for your art.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane looks at her in disbelief.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What for? Jane Eyre adapted by Moira Buffini March 2008 44.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He wishes to have it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To show to his company, I should think. Is this it here? Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane watches helplessly as Mrs Fairfax takes her portfoli

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane is crossing the landing holding Adele's hand. Downstairs, the library doors swing wide open. The sound male laughter can be heard; gentlemen walk out into the hall. Rochester follows, walking with a stick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Monsieur!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All eyes turn upon the landing. Jane tries to find a shad to back into but there are none. Adele curtsies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah, there she is...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is unclear whether he is referring to Adele or Jane. H makes a bow. The men are staring at Jane with great curiosity. It makes her uncomfortable. She tugs Adele awa

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A box tied with ribbons sits on the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ma boite, ma boite!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rochester is leaning against the mantelpiece, drinking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take it away you genuine daughter of Paris and amuse yourself with disembowelling it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll open it together, shall we?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs Fairfax kindly leads Adele away. Jane is about to cro the room with them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miss Eyre. Sit there. Jane Eyre adapted by Moira Buffini March 2008 45.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He gestures to a chair by the fire. Jane obeys. She studi Rochester. He is intent on Adele, who is pulling a pink satin dress out of the box.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not fond of children.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh Ciel! Que c'est beau!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nor do I particularly enjoy simple-minded old ladies. But you might suit me - if you would.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How, sir?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: By distracting me from the mire of my thoughts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Adele, irrepressible, runs across the room embracing the dress. She drops on one knee at Rochester's feet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Monsieur, je vous remercie mille fois de votre bonte...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She looks up, seeking his approval.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That is how Maman used to say, is it not?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Precisely.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's try it on, shall we?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Adele skips off with Mrs Fairfax.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And that is how she charmed my English gold out of my English breeches pocket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rochester notices how keenly Jane is observing him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your gaze is very direct, Miss Eyre? D'you think me handsome?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No sir. Jane Eyre adapted by Moira Buffini March 2008 46.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rochester laughs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was too plain; I beg your pardon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
