dialogues.text: What fault do you find with me? I have all my limbs and all my

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr Rochester, it was a blunder. I ought to have replied that beauty is of little consequence -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now you stick a knife under my

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have other qualities, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just so; other qualities... When I was your age I was a felling enough fellow. I might have been insulted then. You're blushing Miss Eyre.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not at all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And though you're not pretty any more than I am handsome, I must say it becomes you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And now I see you're fascinated by the flowers on the rug.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane senses his mockery.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd like to draw you out. Come, speak to me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about, sir?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The choice of subject is entirely yours.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How can I introduce a subject when I don't know what'll interest you? Jane Eyre adapted by Moira Buffini March 2008 47.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The fact is, Miss Eyre, I don't wish to treat you like an inferior.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yet you'd command me to speak?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well I probably have a right to be a little abrupt and exacting on the grounds of my superiority in age. There must be twenty years between us and a century's advance in experience.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't think you have a right to command me just because you're older. Your claim to superiority depends on the use you've made of your time and experience.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've made indifferent use of both. And this is why I sit, galled by my own thoughts - and order you to divert me. Are you very hurt by my tone of command?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There are few masters who'd trouble to enquire whether their paid subordinates were hurt by their commands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh yes... paid subordinate; I'd forgotten the salary. Well on that mercenary ground, will you consent to speak with me as my equal - without thinking that the request arises from insolence?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd never mistake informality for insolence, sir. One, I rather like. The other, nothing free born should ever submit to - even for a salary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Humbug. Most free-born things would submit to anything for a salary. But I mentally shake hands with you for your answer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane Eyre adapted by Moira Buffini March 2008 48.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not three in three thousand schoolgirl governesses would have answered me as you've just done.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've clearly not spent much time in the company of schoolgirl governesses. I'm the same plain kind of bird as all the rest, with my couple of accomplishments and my common tale of woe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I envy you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your openness, your clear conscience, your unpolluted mind. If I were eighteen I think we truly would be equals. Nature meant me to be a good man, one of the better kind and as you see, I am not so.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you a villain then, sir?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm a trite commonplace sinner, hackneyed in all the dissipations that the rich and worthless try to put on life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When I was your age, fate dealt me a blow. I was - cursed with a burden to carry through life. I lacked the wisdom to remain cool and I turned desperate. Dread remorse, Miss Eyre. It is the poison of life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rochester takes in her open, compassionate face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And since happiness is denied me, I've a right to get pleasure in its stead. And I will get it, cost what it may.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then you'll degenerate still more.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you preaching to me? Jane Eyre adapted by Moira Buffini March 2008 49.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm reminding you of your own words; remorse is the poison of life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But, Miss Eyre, if the pleasure I was seeking was sweet and fresh; if it was an inspiration; if it wore the robes of an angel of light... what then?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. To speak truth, I don't understand you at all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My heart has long been a charnel house. Perhaps it'll transform into a shrine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir, I find the conversation has got out of my depth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're afraid of me because I talk like a sphynx.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not afraid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes you are.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've simply no wish to talk nonsense.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you did it would be in such a grave, quiet manner that I would mistake it for sense. Do you never laugh, Miss Eyre?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This question cuts Jane to the quick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Only rarely, perhaps. But you're not naturally austere, any more than I'm naturally vicious. I can see in you the glance of a curious sort of bird through the close set bars of a cage: a vivid, restless, resolute captive. Were it but free, it would soar. Cloud high.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane opens her mouth to speak - but she cannot. Jane Eyre adapted by Moira Buffini March 2008 50.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane is playing battledore and shuttlecock with Adele. He playing is full of energy, very free. Her cheeks looks almost rosy. It is spring.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just as it turns to come down - that's when you hit it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Adele serves. The game continues apace. Rochester wanders out of the open double doors of the library. He watches.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Something lands at his feet. A rook's feather. He looks u at the battlements. A shape disappears, too fast to see. Rochester's features cloud over with an expression of sha and detestation. He stands in a terrible inner conflict.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane notices him - she misses her shot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mademoiselle has got to rest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because I start to win!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have mercy, Adele. Play with Pilot for a while.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rochester is leaning over the balustrade, his head bowed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is our game disturbing you, sir?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks up. A hard and cynical expression has mastered h countenance, something resolute. Jane is taken aback.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On the contrary. I like your game. I like this cold, hard day. I like Thornfield.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rochester picks up the black feather. He starts to walk across the grounds at a fast pace. Jane follows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've been arranging a point with my destiny, Miss Eyre. My destiny stood up there by that chimney, like one of the hags who appeared to Macbeth. 'You like Thornfield?' She said. 'Like it if you dare'. Well, I dare. It's felt like a plague house for years -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turns, the whole house now in his sights. He shouts: Jane Eyre adapted by Moira Buffini March 2008 51.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But Thornfield is my home and I shall like it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Adele is running after them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mademoiselle - Il faut jouer -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rochester snaps at her with shocking ferocity.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get back! Keep at a distance child, or go in!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Adele's face crumples into tears. Rochester sees Jane's shock at his outburst. He walks away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane isn't sure whether she has been dismissed or not. Adele has run back to Pilot. Jane watches her. She sudden finds Rochester is back at her side. He walks her along.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's the daughter of an opera dancer, Celine Varens. Celine was a beauty and she professed to love me. Her ardour was so great that, ugly as I am, I believed myself her idol. So I installed in her in a hotel, gave her servants, gowns cashmeres, diamonds - in short, I was an idiot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To fall in love, sir?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've never felt love, have you Miss Eyre? Your soul still sleeps.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Does it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're still floating gently in the stream of life, unaware of the rocks ahead waiting to dash you to pieces.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Were you dashed to pieces, Mr Rochester?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not by Celine. How can one ever truly love a woman one has paid for?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane Eyre adapted by Moira Buffini March 2008 52.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It ended when I visited her unexpectedly one night and caught her with her handsome, charmless lover. I overheard her waxing lyrical on all my defects - she was mercenary, heartless, senseless. The whole intoxication fell away like a dream. I left her money to support the little French floweret over there, whom she swore blind was mine. I see no proof of my grim paternity in her features; I think Pilot is more like me than she.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you took her on?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Adele is curled up, seeking comfort from the dog.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some years later, I heard that Celine had abandoned the brat, disappeared to Italy and left it destitute. So I lifted it from the mud and slime of Paris and brought it here, to grow up clean in the wholesome soil of an English country garden. My one good work in a sea of countless sins.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane is looking at Adele full of compassion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You listen, Miss Eyre, as if it was the most usual thing in the world for a man like me to tell stories of his opera-mistresses to an inexperienced girl like you. Adele?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Adele looks up. Rochester speaks graciously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forgive me; for keeping Miss Eyre from your game for so long.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Adele is immensely gratified by his apology.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane, aged ten, is walking along the long gallery. She opens a door and finds herself in the Red Room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She stares into the mirror, searching the pale face of he reflection, as if trying to find an answer. A murmur seem to come down the gaping chimney; a woman's deep sigh. Jane's throat tightens with fear. Something moves in the shadows behind her. Jane Eyre adapted by Moira Buffini March 2008 53.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She scans them, her eyes full of terror. Jane knows beyon all doubt that something is there. She hears a low laugh. It seems to be right next to her. She tries to scream -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane wakes. Her curtains are open; moonlight spilling in. She hears it again; the laugh from her dream, right outsi her door - low and deep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who's there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Footsteps run away. Jane springs out of bed and pulls the door open. A door shuts at the end of the corridor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a single candle burning in its holder on the rus matting, flickering in the draft. Jane picks it up. She notices something else - a curling wreath of grey smoke. She follows its trail through the pitch darkness. It is coming thickly from a half-open door at the front of the house - Rochester's.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane rushes in. Rochester's bed is on fire; the hangings, the curtains, all are alight. The flames are leaping. Rochester is asleep. She shakes him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wake up! Wake up! Sir!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rochester only stirs. The smoke has stupefied him. Jane pulls the burning sheets off - then stops; he is naked. S takes his basin and douses the bed - soaking him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who's there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is I, Jane Eyre, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane takes the ewer and throws water on the curtains. She pulls the soggy fabric from its rail and smothers the burning couch. When all the flames are out, she rushes to the windows and opens them. Smoke billows out. She stands in the moonlight, coughing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rochester is sitting up, staring at her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What in the name of all the elves in Christendom have you done with me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For heaven's sake get up. Somebody has plotted something; you must find out who. I'll light the lamp - Jane Eyre adapted by Moira Buffini March 2008 54.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Light the lamp at your peril.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rochester is springing out of bed. Jane turns away, mortified - having caught sight of his silhouetted shape.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I heard a laugh outside my door loud enough to wake me. I opened it. Someone was running towards the third floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rochester is putting on a dressing gown, lighting the lam

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And a candle was left burning in the middle of the floor. Shall I fetch Mrs Fairfax, sir?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the deuce can she do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then I'll wake John and Martha.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not at all. Stay here. You're shivering.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rochester gets his coat and puts it round her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have to go to the third floor. Don't make a sound. Sit there. I shan't be long.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He goes. Jane looks at his ruined chamber; The blackened drapes on the four poster bed, the fireplace, the huge wardrobe. It is not unlike the red room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Half an hour later. First light. Jane is in an armchair. She has snuggled up in the coat. She takes in a breath, smelling its owner. She nuzzles her head against it. She closes her eyes, running her fingers down the lining.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She looks up. Rochester is watching her. His expression i peculiar. She holds the coat closely around her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you see anything when you opened your chamber door?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Only the candle on the ground. Jane Eyre adapted by Moira Buffini March 2008 55.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you heard a laugh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you heard that laugh before?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's a woman who sews here; Grace Poole - She laughs in that way, I think.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just so. Grace Poole - you have guessed it. Well, you're no talking fool; please say nothing about this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I will account for this state of affairs. Go back to your room and say nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir. (She takes off his coat) Good-night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that how you're going to leave me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You said I should go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rochester approaches her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane, fire is a horrible death. You have saved my life. Don't walk past me as if we were strangers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What am I to do then, sir?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At least... shake hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rochester holds out his hand. Jane takes it. They shake. Rochester wraps Jane's hand in both of his. Jane Eyre adapted by Moira Buffini March 2008 56.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have a pleasure in owing you my life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is no debt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I knew you would do me good in some way. I saw it in your eyes when I first beheld you. Their expression did not - did not strike delight into my very inmost being so, for nothing. People talk of natural sympathies... You.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rochester is drawing her slowly closer. Jane, disconcerte is trying to resist.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good night then, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So you will leave me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm cold.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At last, he relaxes his grip. She backs away. She goes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane is keeling on the windowsill, looking out at the rising sun. She is lit by its glowing rays; inspired. It' a rare feeling that prompts her mood, as new and unfoldin as the day itself - happiness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane looks in to see Leah and Martha cleaning the soot fr the woodwork and windowpanes. To her amazement, Grace Poo is there, calmly sewing rings to new curtains.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good day to you, miss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's happened here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Only master reading in his bed last night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane Eyre adapted by Moira Buffini March 2008 57.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fell asleep with his candle lit and the curtains got on fire. Managed to put it out with the water from his stand. Did you not hear anything, miss?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I did. I heard a strange laugh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's hardly likely the master would laugh when he was in such danger. Perhaps you were dreaming.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then you didn't think of opening your door and looking out?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane is infuriated. She turns on her heel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane walks in. Their meal is laid out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Has Mr Rochester not sent for us today?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why, he's gone away. Were you not aware? He left after breakfast.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane takes this piece of news like an invisible shock.

dialogues.speaker: MRS FAIRFAX, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: He's gone to The Leas, Mr Eshton's place, about ten miles from here. I believe Blanche Ingram is there. She's a great favourite of his.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I saw her two years ago when Mr Rochester had a party here. Oh, she was a beauty; I daresay the most elegant girl I've ever seen. So tall, with raven hair cascading down her back; I don't know how she'd had it done. She sang a duet with Mr Rochester. They made a lovely harmony.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane Eyre adapted by Moira Buffini March 2008 58.

dialogues.speaker: MRS FAIRFAX, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I was quite surprised he didn't make a proposal. Perhaps that is his intention now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane is at the window, brooding. Outside the rain is pouring. Adele, dressed in yellow frills, is concerned.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Qu'avez vous mademoiselle?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (without looking at her) Nothing. Speak in English, please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane turns, expecting to see Adele.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane finds herself in front of her class. They are lookin at her expectantly. She looks back at them curiously. Eag faces, plain rural clothes. She has quite lost her place.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, girls. You may go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane is tidying up at the end of the day. The classroom i empty. Her life is bare. It shows on her face. She looks up. St John Rivers is watching her from the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you find the work too hard?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane immediately puts on a sprightly face and continues clearing up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not at all. I'm getting on very well.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you feel the solitude an oppression?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hardly have time to notice it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then perhaps your accommodations have disappointed you. They are in truth scanty enough - Jane Eyre adapted by Moira Buffini March 2008 59.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A few months ago I had nothing. I was wretched. Now I have a home and work; free and honest. I wonder at the goodness of God and at the generosity of my friends.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: St John approaches her; speaks intimately.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What you had left before I met you, I don't know. But I counsel you to resist firmly every temptation to look back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's what I mean to do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We can overcome every kind of human weakness. A year ago I was myself intensely miserable. I considered my life was so wretched that it must be changed - or I would die. After a season of darkness and struggling, light broke. I heard my call from God. Put your trust in him, Jane. Let him lead you to your future.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: St John is turning to go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why were you intensely miserable?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A year ago, I was weak enough to fall in love.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane moves involuntarily towards him.

dialogues.speaker: ST JOHN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Don't pity me; I have no compassion whatsoever for you. I regarded this love as a fever of the flesh; not a thing that would ever touch my soul. I scorned the weakness, fought hard against it - and won.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane is incredulous. St John is at her desk. It is covere in her drawings. He glances through them. Jane Eyre adapted by Moira Buffini March 2008 60.

dialogues.speaker: ST JOHN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I could have listened to temptation, sunk down in the silken snare and known a feverish and delusive bliss. I could have squandered my future upon it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You could have been happy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A slave in a fool's paradise? I'd rather my life had purpose -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: St John suddenly snatches up a piece of paper.

dialogues.speaker: ST JOHN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Is this yours?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His eyes, in an instant, seem to take in everything about her. He opens his mouth to speak - then checks himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the matter?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing in the world.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He folds the paper and takes it.

dialogues.speaker: ST JOHN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Good night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He goes. Jane looks after him, puzzled.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs Fairfax approaches Jane with a letter in her hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's back in three days he says - heavens that's Thursday - and not alone. He gives directions to prepare all the best rooms. I'm to get more staff from the George Inn. The ladies will bring their maids, the gentlemen, valets. We must accommodate them all. Supplies to be got; linen, the

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs Fairfax has worked herself up into quite a panic. Jane Eyre adapted by Moira Buffini March 2008 61.

dialogues.speaker: MRS FAIRFAX, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I'll get started. I'll go to the George. No, I'll tell Martha...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane can sense that the old lady is overwhelmed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: May I assist you, Mrs Fairfax?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see Mrs Fairfax approach Jane in a rush of gratitude.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane wears a housekeeper's apron over her dress. She ente Rochester's room with an armful of bed linen. It has been returned to its former glory. Adele is jumping up and dow on the bed. Sophie is trying to coax her off it. Jane giv Sophie the sheets.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Adele leaves the room with Jane and skids all the way dow the newly polished gallery in her stockinged feet. Jane can't help smiling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane sets down several bottles of wine on the kitchen tab in order to dust them. The kitchen is a hive of activity except for one lone figure sitting quietly in a chair by the fire, smoking a pipe; Grace Poole. Leah and one of th hired under cooks are talking abut her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She gets good wages, I'd guess?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wish I had as good; not one fifth what Mrs Poole receives.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane affects not to listen, but is keenly interested.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And she's laying it all by. I shouldn't wonder if she's saved enough to keep her independent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's a good hand, I daresay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not everyone could do it, that's for sure, not even for the money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No wonder the master relies on

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane Eyre adapted by Moira Buffini March 2008 62.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leah notices Jane's curious glance. She nudges the under cook. Jane, picks up the bottles and carries them away. A she passes she hears:

dialogues.speaker: UNDER COOK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Doesn't she know?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At that moment, Adele rushes in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're here! They're here!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs Fairfax tries to get her apron off. She becomes flustered. Jane helps her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs Fairfax and Adele go. Jane looks out of the window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Her attention is focussed on two equestrians who lead the arriving party; Rochester and Blanche, the dark beauty at his side. She is laughing at something. The sun shines behind her. Jane is dazzled. She turns away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane comes up the back stairs and on to the gallery, just as the ladies start to issue from their rooms. She stands back in a dark corner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is an approach of chatter; a subdued vivacity. A flurry of multicoloured silks, lace and velvets go by. Th descend the staircase as noiselessly as a bright mist.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane steps out. She walks right into the path of Blanche Ingram, who is dressed in white. They both startle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me, miss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Blanche gives her a look of ice. Rochester is at the top the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good evening.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They both turn. Rochester has seen Blanche, not Jane. He offers her his arm, his gaze full of admiration. Jane sin back into the shadows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: May I?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Blanche lays her gloved hand on Rochester's arm, barely touching him. They glide away. Jane Eyre adapted by Moira Buffini March 2008 63.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Adele and Jane sit on the stairs, listening to Blanche an Rochester sing. Their voices thrill. Jane is trying not t feel. But when Rochester hits an exceptionally beautiful note, she involuntarily closes her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Adele leans into Jane. She is crying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is it, darling?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She sing like Maman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane, full of compassion, takes Adele back to her room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs Fairfax enters in a great hurry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tonight. He wants you both in the drawing room after dinner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Adele leaps up, delighted. Jane is crestfallen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not me, surely.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's his particular wish.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He was being polite.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm instructed to tell you that if you resist, he'll come up and get you himself. You needn't stay long. Just let him see you and then slip away. Don't worry; no one'll look at you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane is delivering Adele into the centre of the company.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: May I present Miss Adele Varens?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bon jour, mesdames, monsieurs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane finds it hard to get a proper impression of the guests, as she cannot raise her eyes to look at them. Jane Eyre adapted by Moira Buffini March 2008 64.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Adele makes a dainty curtsey - pink frock, hair in ringlets, little lace gloves. In the midst of the crowd i Blanche.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why, what a little puppet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (mutton dressed as lamb) Is this your ward, Mr Rochester?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (English rose; nineteen) What a love of a child.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Adele blissfully disappears into a moving sea of dresses. Only one guest is still looking in Jane's direction; Blanche. Her lip curls in distaste.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane backs into a nearby window seat; always her place of refuge. She closes her eyes. A great Atlantic wave hits t sash window behind her, drenching it with foam and brine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When she opens her eyes, Rochester is in her line of vision, standing out in a crowd of unmanly men. He senses her gaze; glances at her. Jane looks down, pulling her wo on to her lap; a beaded purse. She does not lift her eyes from the beads, fully feeling the humiliation of her clas and of her love. Blanche sidles up to Rochester.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought you weren't fond of children?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're right; I'm not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then what induced you to take charge of that little doll?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rochester turns away from Jane.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She was left on my hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why don't you send her to school?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She has a governess.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane glances up; sees Rochester's back to her, throws her eyes down, once more. Jane Eyre adapted by Moira Buffini March 2008 65.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You should hear mamma on the chapter of governesses. I had half a dozen in my day - all detestable, ridiculous incubi - were they not, mamma?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you speak, my lily flower?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I said governesses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The reaction is instant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, don't mention them; the very word makes me nervous! I've suffered a martyrdom from their incompetence and caprice. I thank heaven we're now done with them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have just one word to say of the whole tribe; nuisance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane's fingers sew. Only the briefest flash of her eyes towards the company shows her mortification. Blanche has started playing a brilliant prelude on the piano.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We shall have music - and new subject, if you please. Signor Eduardo, what shall it be?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Donna Bianca, I give you beauty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beauty? Why there's nothing new to be said. I give you back male beauty. Mamma, what's your idea of male beauty?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My son, of course.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hear hear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, Tedo's quite typical of the young men of today. They're so absorbed in the pursuit of fashion that they've forgotten how to be men at all. Jane Eyre adapted by Moira Buffini March 2008 66.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I say -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A woman who neglects herself is a blot on humanity. But a man should pay no heed to his looks. (Glancing at Rochester) A man should possess only strength and valour. He could be a gentleman or a highwayman. His beauty lies in his power.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So a Levantine pirate would do for you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As long as he resembled you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rochester laughs loudly. Jane is heading for the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am serious. To my mind, a man is nothing without a spice of the devil in him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane closes the door on Blanche. She breathes in fresh ai nauseous. Blanche's splendid prelude drifts out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rochester comes into the hall from the other door. Jane instantly bends down and pretends to be tying her shoe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why did you leave the room?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am tired, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why didn't you come and speak to me? I haven't seen you for weeks. It would have been normal and polite to wish me good evening.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You seemed engaged, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What have you been doing while I've been gone?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Teaching Adele.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You look pale. Jane Eyre adapted by Moira Buffini March 2008 67.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am well.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're depressed; your eyes are shining with tears. What's the meaning of this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane catches sight of Mrs Fairfax, who is watching them with an expression of unease. Rochester glares at her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A gentleman has arrived to see you, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He says he's travelled a long way, from Spanish Town, Jamaica -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rochester seems winded.

dialogues.speaker: MRS FAIRFAX, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And indeed I think he must have come from some hot country because he won't take off his coat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Spanish Town...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr Richard Mason. He says you're old friends. I've put him in the morning room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rochester cannot speak.

dialogues.speaker: MRS FAIRFAX, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Have I done wrong?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not at all. Please tell him I'll see him directly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs Fairfax goes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh Jane - Jane. This is a blow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I help you sir?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the drawing room, Blanche's prelude finishes to enthusiastic applause. Rochester has Jane's hand. Jane Eyre adapted by Moira Buffini March 2008 68.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane, if all those people came and spat at me, what would you do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Turn them out of the room sir, if I could.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And if they cast you out for adhering to me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I should care nothing about it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'd dare censure for my sake?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane is frightened of his passion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For the sake of any friend who deserved it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rochester lets her hand go. He steps back. He goes to the morning room. Jane peers through the door, worrying how h last words have given offence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She sees a man rising to meet Rochester; handsome but gau and painfully thin. His smile doesn't reach his eyes - as if his soul is not quite his own.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fairfax...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Richard. How the devil are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They embrace, Rochester doing a fine impression of deligh

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane is standing on the pedestal of infamy, ten years old Helen Burns is walking towards her with something in her arms. The rising sun is all around her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is yours.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane looks down at the bundle. In it, is a newborn boy. Jane looks up to ask Helen for help. But Helen has gone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane alone with her burden, teeters on the stool. The bab starts to cry. Jane panics.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The crying becomes deafening, terrifying. It is not a baby's cry but a human scream. Jane Eyre adapted by Moira Buffini March 2008 69.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane wakes, hearing a savage, sharp shriek of such power and intensity it seems to tear the night in two.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Overhead, the sounds of a struggle begin - a deadly one. Jane hears footsteps rush past her door. She starts to pu on her dress. She hears a man's voice from above:

dialogues.speaker: MASON, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: Help! Rochester, for God's sake come!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A great stamp on the floor above; something falls with a thud; silence. Jane grabs her candle and leaves her room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The guests likewise are all issuing from their rooms; som with candles, some stumbling into the dark. The gallery i filling with terrified ladies and shocked gentlemen. Thei shadows dance grotesquely on the walls.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh what is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who is hurt?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where the devil is Rochester?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rochester comes forth from the door at the end of the gallery, holding a candelabra.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm here, be composed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Blanche flies towards him like a banshee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What awful event has taken place?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She embraces him. Rochester patiently removes her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A servant has had a nightmare, that's all. She's an excitable, nervous person and has taken a fit with fright.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane, the only person behind Rochester, sees by the light of her candle that his dressing gown is trailing blood.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now I must see you back into your rooms because until the house is settled, she can't be properly looked after. Jane Eyre adapted by Moira Buffini March 2008 70.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is there anything I might do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miss Ingram, ladies, please return to your nests like the doves that you are. You'll take cold for certain if you stay in this icy gallery any longer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The candles flicker and fade as the guests make their way back to their rooms. Rochester sees Jane.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come this way. Make no noise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rochester stops by a low door. He puts a key in the lock.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Be steady. I need you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He unlocks it. A room hung with tapestries; a four poster bed with its curtains half drawn. One part of the tapestr is hooked up over a hidden door - which lies open to an inner chamber. A dull, sickly light shines out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He goes to the inner chamber. A grim laugh greets him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, Mrs Poole.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He locks the door. Jane shudders. He goes to the bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here. Bring the candle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane obeys. Richard Mason is lying, one arm and all the linen soaked in blood. Jane controls her reaction and mak herself useful. Rochester is cleaning the wound.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Am I dying?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She bit me - while the knife was in - Bit me - Jane Eyre adapted by Moira Buffini March 2008 71.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was folly to attempt the interview tonight and alone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought I might have done some good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It makes me impatient to hear you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She sucked the blood. Said she'd drain me - like a vampire -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Think of her as dead, dead and buried. Say nothing!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mason is silenced. Rochester puts the bloody sponge into Jane's hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am going for a doctor. I must leave you here with him. Sponge the blood away when it returns. Give him water if he wants it. Do not speak to him for any reason. And Richard - on pain of death - do not speak to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rochester takes the candelabra. He is gone. Mason is staring at Jane. There is something about the pupils in h eyes that she finds deadly, chilling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She dips the sponge in the bloody water and wipes away th trickling gore.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She hears a low moan. She looks over at the door to the inner chamber, aching to know the mystery behind it. Maso makes her start by taking her wrist. He is trying to say something. Jane puts her finger to her lips. She is beggi him not to speak.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rochester and Dr Carter are carrying Mason down the stair

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I only wish I could have got here sooner. He'd not have bled so much.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane, make sure the way is clear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane looks out on to the gallery. She is pale, drawn. Jane Eyre adapted by Moira Buffini March 2008 72.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A carriage waits. Rochester lifts Mason in to Dr Carter. Jane hands in Mason's great coat. She stands back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll ride over tomorrow to see how you do. Goodbye, Richard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fairfax - Let her treated as tenderly as may be -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I do my best and have done it and will do it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The carriage goes. Jane prepares to go inside but Rochest walks her towards the orchard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come, Jane. That house is a dungeon, don't you feel it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It seems to me a splendid mansion, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is slime and cobwebs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The orchard is a different world; the dawn light illuminating dewy trees. Rochester is silent. Jane is trying to fathom him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will Grace Poole stay here now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh yes, don't trouble your head about her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But sir -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grace Poole is not the danger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He walks off, pulling the heads off flowers as he passes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've noticed my tender feelings for Miss Ingram? Jane Eyre adapted by Moira Buffini March 2008 73.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Keep vigil with me again, the night before I marry. For now you've met my lovely one and you know her. She's a rare one, isn't she?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A strapper, a real strapper; big and buxom...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He throws a cankered rose across the orchard. Jane manage to articulate her anxiety.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd do anything for you sir, anything that was right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And if I ever bid you do what was wrong, you'd turn to me, quiet and pale and say 'I cannot do it.' And you'd be as immutable as a fixed star.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rochester, gazing at her, seems to have decided something He turns a corner and is gone. Jane is left alone. We hea the sound of a blow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The brutal face of John Reed, aged fourteen, triumphant after hitting Jane.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's for the look you had on your face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane enters as Rochester helps Blanche to line up a shot. He is leaning intimately over her. She coyly permits him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane has ruined Blanche's shot. Jane Eyre adapted by Moira Buffini March 2008 74.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Does that creeping creature want you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rochester has followed Jane out of the billiard room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you please, I want leave of absence for a week or two.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What to do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane shows him the letter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is from my old nurse, Bessie. She says my cousin John Reed is dead. He ruined himself and has committed suicide. The news has so shocked his mother, my Aunt, that it's brought on a stroke.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What good can you do her?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's been asking for me. I parted from her very badly and I can't neglect her wishes now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Promise me you won't stay long.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir, it seems you are soon to be married.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What of it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Adele should go to school.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To get her out of my bride's way who might otherwise trample her?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And I must seek another situation. I intend to advertise. Jane Eyre adapted by Moira Buffini March 2008 75.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At your peril you advertise. Trust it to me. I'll find you a good situation in time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is on the point of returning to the billiard room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And sir? Forgive me but I have had no wages as yet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How much do I owe you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fifteen pounds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rochester looks in his wallet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here's fifty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's too much.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take your wages.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I cannot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then I only have a ten.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now you owe me five.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just so. Come back for it quickly. Meantime, I shall safeguard it in here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He taps the wallet, which is in his breast pocket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you trust me to keep it, Jane?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not a whit, sir. You are not to be trusted at all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rochester strides away, grinning. Jane turns. Jane Eyre adapted by Moira Buffini March 2008 76.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bessie, now housekeeper, is moving forward to meet Jane.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bless you! - I knew you'd come.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They embrace.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bessie... I'm not too late? How is Mrs Reed?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She may linger yet a while. She's spoken of you daily. At first we couldn't tell what she was saying but when her speech came clear we heard 'Jane Eyre, get Jane Eyre.'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shall I see her now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll take you up directly. But look at you. What a lady you've become. Why you're almost pretty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane takes her aunt's hand. Mrs Reed looks very near deat

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aunt Reed? It is Jane Eyre. You sent for me, and here I am.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs Reed, with an effort, pulls her hand away from Jane's

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No one knows the trouble I have with that child. Such a burden. Left on my hands. Speaking to me like a fiend. The fever at Lowood. She should have died!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why do you hate her so?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Her mother. Reed's sister - his beloved. When news came of her death he wept like a fool. Sent for the baby. Sickly thing - not strong like mine. But Reed loved it. Kept it by his bed. Made me vow to bring the creature up. Why did he not love mine? Jane Eyre adapted by Moira Buffini March 2008 77.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The words are a revelation to Jane. Mrs Reed gazes at her

dialogues.speaker: MRS REED, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Who are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am Jane Eyre, Aunt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You. Is there no one in the room?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane motions Bessie to go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We are alone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've twice done you wrong. I broke the vow I made to Reed -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please, don't think of it -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am dying; I must get it out!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs Reed indicates a box on her bedside table.

dialogues.speaker: MRS REED, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Open that box. Take out the letter. Read it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane obeys. She reads the letter aloud.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Madam, will you have the goodness to send me the address of my niece, Jane Eyre. I desire her to come to me at Madeira. Fortune has blessed my endeavours and as I am childless I wish to adopt her and bequeath her at my death whatever I may have to leave. Yours, John Eyre, Madeira.'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane is stunned.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is dated three years ago. Why did I never hear of it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because I wrote and told him you had died of typhus at Lowood school. You fury. You were born to be my torment. I'll never forget how you turned on me and raged.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane Eyre adapted by Moira Buffini March 2008 78.

dialogues.speaker: MRS REED, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You called the names of the dead down upon me. I was afraid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forgive me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You cursed me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I would have loved you if you'd let me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My life has been cursed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please, let us be reconciled.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs Reed shrinks from Jane's touch. Jane wipes her tears.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then love me or hate me as you will. You have my full and free forgiveness. Now ask for God's - and be at peace.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs Reed's eyes close.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The morning sun is pouring in. Jane goes to the bed. She puts her hand upon it, gently, as if thanking her uncle f all he did. She notices a picture on the wall. A miniatur of a brown-haired woman with elfin eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane takes it off the wall. Bessie comes in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My mother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bessie nods. A tear rolls down Jane's face. She clasps th picture, looking round the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why ever was I so afraid?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A coach pulls up in the lane near Thornfield. Jane gets out. We hear her voice.

dialogues.speaker: JANE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: My dear uncle, some years ago, my Aunt Reed mistakenly informed you that I had died. Jane Eyre adapted by Moira Buffini March 2008 79.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane is walking through the wooded glade where she first met Rochester. All is green and verdant and bathed in sunset light. There seems to be life everywhere.

dialogues.speaker: JANE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I am writing to tell you that I am very much alive and living at Thornfield Hall, where I am currently governess to the ward of Mr Edward Fairfax Rochester -

dialogues.speaker: ROCHESTER, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: There you are.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane turns. Rochester is sitting on the stile where they first met. For a moment, her every nerve is unstrung.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just like one of your tricks to steal into your home along with the twilight. Where the deuce have you been this last month?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have been with my aunt sir, who is dead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rochester laughs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A true Janian reply. If I dared I'd touch you, to see if you were real...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane puts out her hand. Rochester takes it. He helps Jane over the stile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go home - stay your wandering feet at a friend's threshold.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane lets go of his hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you Mr Rochester. I'm strangely glad to get back again to you. Wherever you are is my home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane, knowing she has said too much, turns and runs over the fields towards Thornfield.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane is on a low seat, Adele nestling close to her. Jane Eyre adapted by Moira Buffini March 2008 80.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're expecting the announcement very soon. He went down to London only last week to buy her a new carriage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then we must accept it. He'll soon bring home his bride.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs Fairfax nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane is alone, drinking in the beauty of the evening - looking at the gardens as if she may never see them again She turns a corner and sees Rochester staring intently at something. His back is to her. She is about to tiptoe awa

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come and look at this fellow, Jane.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane approaches, wondering how he has sensed her presence Rochester is looking at a huge moth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look at his wings. He looks West Indian - I have never seen one like him, here. There; flown.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They watch the moth as it flies towards the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thornfield is a pleasant place in summer, isn't it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll be sad to leave it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, but it can't be helped. I soon hope to be a bridegroom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you found me a new situation, sir?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A situation, yes of course. It's the least I can do for a faithful paid subordinate such as yourself. You're to undertake the education of the five daughters of Mrs Dionysus O'Gall of Bitternut Lodge, Connaught. Jane Eyre adapted by Moira Buffini March 2008 81.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Connaught?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll like Ireland. They're such warm-hearted people, they say.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is a long way away, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From here. From you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We've been good friends, Jane haven't we? But with the Irish sea between us you'd soon forget me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane's great distress escapes her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wish I could. I wish I'd never come here. I love Thornfield - I've lived a full life here. I've not been trampled on or petrified or buried with inferior minds. I've talked face to face with what I reverence, with what I delight in. I've known you Mr Rochester -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then why must you be torn from me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because of your bride.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have no bride.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you will have.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, I will.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then I must go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You must stay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you think I could stay to become nothing to you? Am I an automaton, a machine without feelings?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane Eyre adapted by Moira Buffini March 2008 82.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you think that because I am poor, obscure, plain and little that I am soulless and heartless?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have as much soul as you and full as much heart. I'm not speaking to you through mortal flesh. It's my spirit that addresses your spirit as if we'd passed through the grave and stood at God's feet, equal - as we are.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rochester takes Jane in his arms.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As we are.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane struggles away from him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm a free human being with an independent will, which I now exert to leave you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rochester releases her. She stands in front of him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then let your will decide your destiny. I offer you my hand, my heart and a share of all this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He gestures towards the house, the land. Jane is stunned.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I ask you to pass through life at my side. Jane, you are my equal and my likeness. It is you I intend to marry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you mocking me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you doubt me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Entirely. Jane Eyre adapted by Moira Buffini March 2008 83.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have no faith in me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not a whit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You little sceptic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your bride is Miss Ingram -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What love have I for Miss Ingram? What love has she for me? I caused a rumour to reach her that my fortune was lost and got instant coldness. I wanted to make you jealous, to move you to love me. It's you - you strange, unearthly thing. I love you as my own flesh. You - poor and obscure as you are - please accept me as your husband.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane begins to believe him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you in earnest?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I must have you for my own.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You wish me to be your wife?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I swear it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You love me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then sir, I will marry you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They embrace.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Neither Jane nor Rochester moves. Darkness is almost complete. Still the intensity of the embrace is held.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It will atone. It will atone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A sheet of lightning momentarily lights up the sky. Some moments later a distant rumble of thunder. Jane Eyre adapted by Moira Buffini March 2008 84.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is teeming with rain. Rochester and Jane run to the front entrance. He holds his jacket around her. Lightning They reach the dry hearth inside. Thunder. They are both euphoric, breathless, laughing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I must go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good night. Good night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He kisses her. They kiss again. Jane will not let him go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Jane runs upstairs she sees Mrs Fairfax, deeply shocke

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane wears a lilac gown. Mrs Fairfax is very concerned.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you accepted him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well I never would have thought.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane is hurt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Am I a monster? Is it so impossible that Mr Rochester should love me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I've long noticed that you were a sort of pet of his. But you're so young and so little acquainted with men. I don't want to grieve you child, but let me put you on your guard. Gentlemen in his position... Let's just say they're not accustomed to marry their governesses. Until you are wed, distrust yourself as well as him. Please, keep him at a distance -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane has heard enough. She turns away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you. Jane Eyre adapted by Moira Buffini March 2008 85.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane, walking through, finds herself in Rochester's arms. She laughs as he raises her off the ground.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is this my pale elf? This sunny faced girl with the radiant eyes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is I, Jane Eyre sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Soon to be Jane Rochester.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It can never be, sir. Human beings were not meant to enjoy complete happiness on this earth. It's too much like a fairy tale.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let the fairy tale begin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rochester is rolling out reams of beautiful silks. Jane gets more uncomfortable as she looks at them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This morning I wrote to my banker in London to send certain jewels. In a day or two I hope to pour them into you lap -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, no sir -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I will put the diamond chain around your neck myself -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't want jewels -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll dress you in these satins -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then you won't know me. I'll not be Jane Eyre any longer but an ape in a harlequin's jacket. Put them away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane pushes the silks away. Jane Eyre adapted by Moira Buffini March 2008 86.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well for cool native impudence and pure innate pride, you haven't your equal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm naturally proud. And hard and flinty. You ought to know what sort of bargain you've made while you've still got time to rescind it. I want only one thing from you, Mr Rochester.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And what's that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your regard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane puts her arm through Rochester's. He smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's your time now, little tyrant but it'll soon be mine and when I have seized you, to have and to hold, I'll attach you to a chain, like this...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rochester flicks his watch into the air.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A summer gale. The moan of the wind sounds almost human. The light is sickly, nightmarish.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A great box sits on the table, which Jane is opening. Adele, Sophie and Mrs Fairfax are all looking on. Jane pulls out a pearl coloured wedding gown. She is dismayed its opulence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She holds it up to herself. Adele starts to play with the great veil. She wraps it round herself. She becomes caugh in it, tangled, distressed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Adele?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane wakes. There is a candle alight at the end of her be Her eyes focus. Her wardrobe is open. Jane is unnerved.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Adele, is that you? Jane Eyre adapted by Moira Buffini March 2008 87.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A form emerges, a woman, tall and gaunt, with thick, blac hair hanging down her back. She is dressed in a nightgown like a shroud. Over her head, she wears Jane's bridal vei a phantom bride.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane is paralysed with terror.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The form takes the veil and slowly tears it in half; bruised arms, dirt, predatory nails, neglect. The last thing to be revealed is the woman's face, pale and ghastl Her eyes are glittering with hatred.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The figure takes the candle and bends down to Jane. Her intention looks deadly. Jane's breath catches. She cannot breathe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The figure moves closer, then blows out the candle. Darkness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane wakes, lying half out of the bed. The veil is over her. She flings it away from her face. Jane sits, her terror dawning. Her breath comes in great dry sobs. She i shocked to find herself still alive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane is waiting, pale with anxiety. A man on horseback approaches, a great dog at his side; Rochester. He is grinning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He pulls Jane up on the horse in front of him. She curls into his arms, desperate for his comfort and his strength Rochester senses something is wrong. He slows the horse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm afraid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rochester holds the torn veil in his hands. He is aghast. He cannot think what to say.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane, this is the only explanation. It must have been half-dream, half- reality. A woman did enter your room last night and that woman was - must have been - Grace Poole - Jane Eyre adapted by Moira Buffini March 2008 88.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was not Grace Poole.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rochester keeps talking over her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know how strange she is. What did she do to me? To Mason? In a state between sleeping and waking -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was not asleep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You noticed her entrance and her actions but you've ascribed to her an appearance different from her own. That was your nightmare -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know what I saw.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I see you'd ask why I keep such a woman in my house. When we've been married a year and a day, I promise I'll tell you. Are you satisfied Jane? Do you accept my solution?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane clearly doesn't. Rochester takes her in his arms.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dear God. It was only the veil...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane is in an unadorned pearl wedding gown.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mademoiselle...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Adele gives her a small bouquet. Jane hugs her, very move as if she is leaving her childhood behind. She turns to g

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please, you must look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane gazes stupefied at the stranger in the mirror.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rochester is waiting at the bottom of the stairs for Jane She slows when she sees him. She finds she cannot speak. Neither can he.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs Fairfax is by the door. Jane can't find words for her Jane Eyre adapted by Moira Buffini March 2008 89.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rochester grips her hand. They quit the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rochester, grimly resolute, is striding at a pace Jane ca hardly follow. Her satin shoes are muddy. She is becoming breathless. A rook flies over their heads, cawing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rochester is striding purposefully towards a small church of ancient design. Jane stumbles. Rochester is contrite.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane tries to collect herself. She looks up to the sky. T rook wheels around the spire. She takes Rochester's hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At the altar, Jane glances at Rochester. He is looking straight ahead at the clergyman, Wood.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I require and charge you both, as ye will answer at the dreadful day of judgement when the secrets of all hearts shall be revealed, that if either of you know any impediment why ye may not be lawfully joined together in matrimony, ye do now confess it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is not a sound. Rochester still doesn't look at Jan The clergyman prepares the rings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Edward Fairfax Rochester, do you

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A commotion at the back of the church. Two men rapidly enter. One of them Briggs, hurries up the aisle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The marriage cannot go on. I declare the existence of an impediment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rochester moves, shaken.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Proceed. Jane Eyre adapted by Moira Buffini March 2008 90.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The ceremony is quite broken off. An insuperable impediment to this marriage exists.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Proceed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr Rochester has a wife now living.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wood is utterly dismayed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where is your proof?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Briggs starts to read out a document.

dialogues.speaker: BRIGGS, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: I affirm and can prove that Edward Fairfax Rochester was fifteen years ago married to my sister, Bertha Antoinetta Mason at St James church, Spanish Town, Jamaica.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane looks at Rochester. She forces him to look at her. H denies nothing; defies everything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The record of the marriage will be found in the register of that church - a copy of it is now in my possession. Signed, Richard Mason.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rochester turns to Briggs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That does not prove that my wife is still living.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She was living two months ago.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do you know?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have a witness to the fact.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Produce him or go to hell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The figure by the door steps out of the shadows. It is Richard Mason. Rochester flies down the aisle, a groan of rage escapes him. He lifts his arm. Jane Eyre adapted by Moira Buffini March 2008 91.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good God -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir, you are in a sacred place -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mason flinches away. Rochester swallows his rage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What have you to say?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She is at Thornfield Hall. I saw her there in April. I'm her brother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A grim smile contorts Rochester's lips. He turns towards Jane. She remains where she was abandoned - at the altar tiny, under he vaulted arch. The bouquet falls from her hand. Rochester walks to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This girl knew nothing. She thought all was fair and legal. She never dreamt she was going to be entrapped into a feigned union with a defrauded wretch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A tiny breath is the only noise Jane utters. Rochester pulls her from the altar to his side.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come, Jane, come all of you and meet Mrs Poole's charming patient. Come and meet my wife.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sun outside is blinding. Jane closes her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rochester enters pulling Jane after him, her hand still i his iron grip. Wood, Mason and Briggs follow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs Fairfax, Adele, Sophie, Martha and Leah are waiting. Adele runs forward. Rochester stops her in her tracks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get back! Do not come near! Go, all of you - keep your congratulations - they come fifteen years too late!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Adele has crumpled into frightened tears. Mrs Fairfax has her hand over her mouth, pale with shock. Jane meets her eye as Rochester pulls her up the stairs. A revelation. Jane Eyre adapted by Moira Buffini March 2008 92.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The tapestried room. Rochester glances at Mason. He unloc the inner door with one hand; the other won't let go of Jane. Grace Poole sits by a strongly guarded fire, stirri something in a pot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
