dialogues.text: Rochester leads Jane and the men into the room. There is window, no furniture except for Grace's chair; only a mattress on the floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir, you can't be bringing folk in here. It's madness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bertha Antoinetta Mason stands, amazed at the sight of he visitors. She wears a white shift. There are black rook feathers twined in her hair; her only ornament.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This clothed hyena is my wife.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bertha's pose is dignified, her expression grows triumphant. She approaches Rochester - her eyes locked wi Jane's. Jane gazes: fear, disgust, compassion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was duped into marriage with this lunatic fifteen years ago.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Briggs and Wood are deeply repelled.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let us go. We have seen enough.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bertha puts her arm through Rochester's; lays her head on his shoulder; smiles at Jane, magnanimous in her victory.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My own demon, Bertha.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With shocking speed and strength Bertha lays her nails in Rochester's cheek. He struggles with her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grace assists Rochester. They do not hit; they subdue. Bertha's attack is effectively contained. They have her o her knees, her arms behind her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bertha lifts her head and screams. If a scream could express the agony of a whole soul then this would. Jane turns on her heels. She stumbles, finds the door, exits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane is coming down the stairs. Briggs is at her side. Jane Eyre adapted by Moira Buffini March 2008 93.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You, madam, are clearly not to blame. Your uncle will be glad to hear it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane looks at Briggs, only dimly comprehending him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You wrote to your uncle, did you not? To inform him you were going to marry Mr Rochester? Mr Mason was staying with him when your letter came.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Briggs gets only a blank look of puzzlement from Jane.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr John Eyre has been the Madeira correspondent of the Mason trading house for some years. You can imagine his distress when Mason revealed the real state of matters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane starts walking towards the sanctuary of her room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He would have come himself but I'm sad to tell you that his health is in mortal decline. He implored Mr Mason to prevent this false marriage and referred him to me for assistance. I only hope that he survives long enough to hear that you are safe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane opens her door. She turns to Briggs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She shuts the door on Briggs and on the world.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane sits on her bed. She mechanically starts taking off the blond square she has worn as a veil.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane, standing in stillness with the pearl dress crumpled around her feet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane Eyre adapted by Moira Buffini March 2008 94.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane has taken a black stuff dress off its hangar. She slowly puts her arms around it, as if it is her old self. She holds it, her eyes staring at nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane in her underclothes, sitting down on the bed. She closes her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane lies curled up on a rock at the bottom of a dried-up river bed. All of nature is suspended in stillness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Far away, we hear the sound of a flood loosened in the remote mountains. We hear the sound of the torrent approach.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane doesn't move. She has no will to flee. The sound of rushing water pounds in her ears. She lies, waiting to be dashed away. We see the flood approach and hit. A dazzlin whiteness of water and foam.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane's room is entirely unchanged except for the fact tha it is full of river water from floor to ceiling. Her bedding, furniture and belongings all sit in the room as normal - underwater.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The light shines murkily in through the window to reveal Jane floating, suspended. Her hair and her garments trail out. She is alive. But she is drowned.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The moon has risen. Jane is lying in an exhausted doze on the bed. She wakes; sits up. She is faint. She recovers herself. She knows what she must do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane, dressed in black in the silver light, putting her brush, comb and brooch in a bag. She looks in her purse. She has some coins.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane unbolts her door, takes a step out of her room, and stumbles into Rochester's arms. He has been keeping guard

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane Eyre adapted by Moira Buffini March 2008 95.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His cheek has been cut by Bertha's nails.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Five minutes more of that death- like hush and I'd have forced the lock.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He examines her face. He is desperate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No tears. Your heart has been weeping blood. Forgive me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rochester buries his head in Jane's arms. She automatical comforts him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How could I? I am a worthless sinner. Don't spare me. Rain your tears up on me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I cannot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I deserve a hail of fire.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane extricates herself from his embrace.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm tired and sick. I need some water.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rochester perceives Jane's inanition. He carries her down the gallery. Jane clings on to her bag of belongings. She has nothing else left.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rochester has lain Jane in front of the fire. She forces herself to eat. Rochester gives her wine. She sips.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How are you now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Much better, sir. I shall be well again soon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rochester paces away to the fire. He comes back. Stoops h head down to Jane to kiss her. She turns her head away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know you. You are thinking. Talking is no use; you are thinking how to act. Jane Eyre adapted by Moira Buffini March 2008 96.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All is changed, sir. I must change too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. There is no doubt that we both must change. I was wrong ever to keep you here; this narrow stone vault with its one real fiend. I'll shut it up. I'll pay Mrs Poole two hundred a year to care for its inmate and then no one will be harmed when she is prompted to burn people, to stab them, to bite the flesh from their bones -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir - you speak of her with hate - it is cruel. She cannot help being mad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not because she's mad that I hate her. If you were mad do you think that I'd hate you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then you know nothing about me, nothing about the way I love. Your mind is my treasure - and if it were broken it would be my treasure still. You are my sympathy, my better self, my angel. I will wrap my whole existence round you. Let us leave here tomorrow. Come with me - as my wife.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll pledge you my fidelity -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll live a happy, most innocent life -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I must leave you, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rochester cannot take this in. Jane Eyre adapted by Moira Buffini March 2008 97.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't you love me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I do love you - But I mustn't show it or speak it ever again. I must begin a new existence - strange scenes among strange faces. I must part from you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Must be a part of me; that's what you mean. You are my wife, Jane. In truth -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have a wife already.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was tricked, duped into wedlock with that demon-hate, that harlot, that succubus upstairs. My father wanted her money and so I was sent to Spanish Town and the match was made. I hardly spoke with her. I was dazzled, ignorant, raw. My senses were besotted and I married her - gross, grovelling mole-eyed blockhead that I was.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rochester sits, staring at the fire.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I lived with her for four years. She dragged me through all the degrading agonies which attend those bound to the intemperate and unchaste. Her excesses developed germs of madness and the doctors shut her up. One night, unable to bear her screaming hate and knowing I could never be rid of her, I put a gun to my head to kill myself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane is both appalled and moved.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I would have pulled the trigger, died in that tropical place but for a breeze which blew in from the sea and smelt of home. With it, I came to my senses. Bertha Antoinetta Mason had abused my long suffering, sullied my name, outraged my honour and blighted my youth. It was enough. At that moment, as I decided to live, she ceased to be my wife.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane Eyre adapted by Moira Buffini March 2008 98.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Only my father and brother knew of the marriage and by then they were both dead. I let my connection with her be buried in oblivion and I brought her here. I have seen that she's cared for as her condition demands and that is all that God and humanity asks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I earnestly pity you, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He sees that Jane is silently crying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane, it's not pity that I see in your face. It's not pity -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do not say it -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is love.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They are holding each other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was wrong to deceive you. It was cowardly. I should have appealed to your spirit - as I do now - should have opened my life, described my hunger for a better existence - shown you my chains. I give you my life. I give you my pledge. Please, be my wife.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You would be my equal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I would make it so.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You once told me that hiring a mistress is the next worse thing to buying a slave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not my mistress - Jane Eyre adapted by Moira Buffini March 2008 99.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I would not degrade you by having you live with a slave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I said wife, my wife -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane tries to rise. Rochester keeps hold of her hand. He gently pulls her down again. Comforts her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you really mean to leave me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He kisses her gently, lovingly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you mean it now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He runs his hands over her, with great tenderness. Jane offers no resistance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh Jane...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rochester lays her down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What friends would you offend by living with me? Who would be injured? Who would care?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane is almost lost. She speaks in a small voice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I would.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane, it would not be wicked to love me...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It would be to obey you. I care for myself. Jane Eyre adapted by Moira Buffini March 2008 100.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane's resolve grows. She resists.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The more alone, the more friendless, unsustained I am, the more I must respect myself -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will you listen to me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I must listen to myself -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will you hear reason?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me go -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because if you won't I'll try violence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane instantly stops resisting. She looks at him with utt shock. He is above her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I could bend you with my finger and thumb; a mere reed you feel in my hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane neither moves nor speaks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But your eye; resolute, free. What ever I do with this cage I cannot get at you. And it is you, soul, that I want. Why don't you come of your own free will here, to my heart? Oh come, Jane, come -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: God help me!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All the life seems to go out of Rochester. He lets Jane g She pulls herself away from him. She stands. He remains, his face buried.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She goes to the door. Rochester turns his eyes to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have never called me by my name. My name is Edward.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane cannot speak it. She turns away. Jane Eyre adapted by Moira Buffini March 2008 101.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: First light. Jane is running; flushed, breathless, her dress soaked with dew. She has her bag of belongings over her shoulder. She trips; falls to her knees.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She looks back. For a moment she seems paralysed. She returns her gaze to the route ahead. Her need to escape i so great that she crawls forwards until she is able to raise herself to her feet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She reaches the stile; lifts herself on to it; puts her arms around the post. She holds it, as if it were beloved Her eyes close. We hear the sound of a winter blizzard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane opens her eyes. She is sitting at her fireside. Outside, a snowstorm howls. On her knee is a sketchbook. She looks down at it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rochester's dark eye is beginning to appear on her paper. She puts a line through it; scribbles it out, blinding hi She stands up, trying to escape her thoughts. She whisper

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Edward.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a loud knock on the door. Jane starts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane opening the door. Rochester is there, standing in th frozen hurricane and howling darkness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane pulls him inside. She falls into his arms. They embrace passionately. Jane is actively pulling him toward her, delirious with love and longing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The exact same shot of Jane opening the door. St John Rivers is there, having waded through the drifting snow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr St John - What on earth brings you away from your hearth on a night like this? Has anything happened? There's no bad news I hope?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How easily alarmed you are. Jane Eyre adapted by Moira Buffini March 2008 102.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He takes off his cloak; stamps the snow off his boots.

dialogues.speaker: ST JOHN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: The snow was up to my waist at one point.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You are recklessly rash about your own health.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nonsense.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: St John's eyes alight on Jane's charcoal drawing. Jane snatches it away too late. There is a moment of silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why are you come?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An inhospitable question.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I mean on a night like this -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got tired of my mute books and empty rooms. Besides I've been told half a story and I'm most impatient to find out the end.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane motions to St John to sit. He doesn't. She becomes increasingly uneasy as he speaks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Twenty years ago, a poor curate fell in love with a rich man's daughter and married her. She was disowned by her family and two years later the rash pair were both dead. They left a daughter which charity received into her lap - as cold as that snow drift I almost stuck fast in. Charity carried the friendless thing to the house of its rich maternal relations. It was reared by an aunt-in-law; I come to names now - Mrs Reed of Gateshead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane starts. She is on her feet.

dialogues.speaker: ST JOHN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Mrs Reed kept the orphan ten years and at the end of that time she was sent to Lowood school.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane Eyre adapted by Moira Buffini March 2008 103.

dialogues.speaker: ST JOHN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It seems her career there was very honourable. She became a teacher like yourself, and left it, like yourself, to be a governess. She undertook the education of the ward of a certain Mr Rochester -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr Rivers! -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can guess your feelings but hear me to the end. Of Mr Rochester's character I know nothing but he professed to offer honourable marriage to this young girl and at the very altar she discovered that he had a wife yet alive. His subsequent conduct is a matter of pure conjecture but when the governess was enquired after it was discovered that she had fled Thornfield Hall and no trace of her has since been found. Now isn't that an odd tale?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Since you know so much, perhaps you can tell me how he is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr Rochester; how is he?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm ignorant of all concerning him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: St John opens his pocket book and removes a piece of pape

dialogues.speaker: ST JOHN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Well, since you won't ask the governess's name, I must tell you. I have it written down here in black and white.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He hands her the paper. On it are doodled the heads of so of her pupils. She has absently written Jane Eyre in the margin several times.

dialogues.speaker: ST JOHN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: A solicitor named Briggs wrote to me of a Jane Eyre. I knew a Jane Elliott. This paper resolved my suspicion into certainty. Jane Eyre adapted by Moira Buffini March 2008 104.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The solicitor - Mr Briggs - does he have any news of Mr Rochester?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you not going to enquire why he has gone to such lengths to find you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What does he want with me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Merely to tell you that your uncle, Mr John Eyre of Madeira, is dead; that he has left you all his property and that you are now rich.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You are rich; quite an heiress.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Silence. Jane is flabbergasted.

dialogues.speaker: ST JOHN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Your fortune is vested in the English funds; Briggs has the will and all the necessary documents. You can enter on immediate possession.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At last, Jane looks questioningly up at him.

dialogues.speaker: ST JOHN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Your forehead unbends at last; I thought you were turning to stone. Perhaps now you will ask how much you are worth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How much am I worth?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh a trifle. Twenty thousand pounds - but what of that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The news literally takes Jane's breath away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Twenty thousand pounds?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: St John begins to laugh at Jane's reaction. She has never seen him laugh before. Jane Eyre adapted by Moira Buffini March 2008 105.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you'd committed a murder and I'd found you out, you could scarcely look more aghast.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There must be some mistake. It's two thousand, surely.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's twenty. You look desperately miserable about it, I must say.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane still cannot take it in. She frowns in disbelief.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why did Mr Briggs write to you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You see, that is the strange thing. It makes me wonder what power or providence led you to our door. Your name is Jane Eyre.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then I'm you namesake. I was christened St John Eyre Rivers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: St John Eyre -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My mother had two brothers, one was a clergyman, your father, the other was John Eyre of Madeira. Mr Briggs wrote to inform us that the clergyman's daughter was lost. I have been able to find her out; that is all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your mother was my father's sister?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My uncle John was your uncle John?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That is correct. Jane Eyre adapted by Moira Buffini March 2008 106.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So you, Diana and Mary -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We are cousins, yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane is deeply moved.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I am glad! - I am glad!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She throws her arms around St John. Tears of happiness start to flow. He, finding it peculiar to be held, gently tries to calm her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here you are neglecting essential points to pursue trifles. You were utterly downhearted when I told you that you were rich and now, for a matter of no moment, you are deliriously happy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of no moment? You have sisters and maybe don't care for a cousin but I have nobody. I have been alone, always. And now three relations are born into my world full grown. Oh, I am glad. You, who saved my life -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You must try to tranquillise your feelings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane finally releases him, still radiant with joy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Write to Diana and Mary. Tell them to hand in notice and come home. They will have five thousand each and so will you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've told you the news too quickly. You're confused.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't put me out of patience, cousin. I am rational enough. Twenty thousand divided equally between the nieces and nephews of our uncle, gives five to each.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is acting on first impulse. You don't know what it is to have

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane Eyre adapted by Moira Buffini March 2008 107.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And you cannot imagine - family - I never had a home. I never had brothers and sisters -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A terrible thought occurs to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You are not reluctant to own me, are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: St John takes her hand. She has surprised and moved him. looks at her, seeing her anew.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane, I will be your brother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane, Diana and Mary are running over the moors. Mary has kite. They are as delighted as children.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane is sitting at the table letting Diana style her hair They all have new summer dresses on. There is a lightness to all three as if a great weight has been lifted from their shoulders.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Diana is setting Jane's hair into curls like her own. Jan looks at herself in the mirror; softer, gentler, differen

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The girls each have a candle. St John kisses Mary. He kisses Diana.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You call Jane your sister but you don't treat her as such. You should kiss her too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane turns to Diana, embarrassed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Di, you are very provoking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As she turns back, she finds St John's face right in fron of her. He kisses her. A kiss with no warmth; an experiment. He examines its effect. He is satisfied. Jane Eyre adapted by Moira Buffini March 2008 108.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane closes the door. She puts her hand across her lips. The icy kiss has agonised her with the full force of her loneliness. She curls up in a ball, desperate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A glorious summer sunset. Jane is digging at a flower bed putting all her passion into the task. She is flushed wit exertion. St John watches.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You are wasted here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Am I not being useful?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You should look beyond Moor House, beyond the selfish calm and comfort of affluence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beyond to what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I go to India in six weeks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So soon? -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: St John draws Jane away from her work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can see what your gifts are and why they were given. Come with me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane is utterly crestfallen.

dialogues.speaker: ST JOHN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: God and nature intended you for a missionary's wife. You are formed for labour not for love. I want to claim you - not for my pleasure but for God's service.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not fit for it. I have no vocation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're far too humble. Jane Eyre adapted by Moira Buffini March 2008 109.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: St John have mercy. I feel my mind shrinking -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't be afraid. You are diligent, faithful, docile, courageous, gentle and heroic. Cease to mistrust yourself. I trust you unreservedly. Let me give you time to think. But know this; in you, I recognise a fellow soul, a soul that would revel in the flame and excitement of sacrifice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane is chilled to the bone by his words. St John leaves the garden and walks away over the moors.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane leaning against the garden wall, trying to think, trying to compose herself. The sun is setting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane carrying a candle, opens the door. St John is at the table working by lamp light. The moon shines brightly in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I used to long for a life of action, to overleap the horizon, to move in the world of men. Maybe God is giving me this. And what is there for me here? Pain and longing for what can't be. I don't know how long I would survive in India. My frame isn't strong. But I'll go with you, if I may go free.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Free?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You and I had better not marry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why not?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because I am your sister.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you'll go with me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Conditionally - as your curate. Jane Eyre adapted by Moira Buffini March 2008 110.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane, I don't need a curate; I need a wife.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I must have my heart and mind free, my own self to turn to. I couldn't become part of you -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A part of me you must become or the whole bargain is void. How can I, a man not yet thirty take out to India a girl of nineteen, unless she is my wife? Don't offer God half a sacrifice. He must have all. And undoubtedly enough of love would follow to make the union right, even in your eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane is shocked.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Enough of love?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, quite enough.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: St John, I scorn your idea of love. I scorn the counterfeit sentiment you offer and I scorn you when you offer it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: St John is mortified. A slow rage begins to boil in him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've uttered nothing that deserves scorn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forgive me but the very name of love is an apple of discord between us. My dear cousin, please abandon your scheme of marriage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No; and if you reject it, it's not me you deny but God.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane is stung. St John has turned from her. His face is i in the moonlight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do not be angry with me please. It makes me wretched. I want us to be friends. Jane Eyre adapted by Moira Buffini March 2008 111.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We are friends. I hope we can be more.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I cannot come as your wife.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why this refusal? It makes no sense!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If I were to marry you, you'd kill me. You're killing me now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd kill you? I am killing you? Your words are violent, unfeminine and untrue -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'd kill me without drawing any blood or receiving on your conscience any stain of crime.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What nonsense is this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'd experience no pain - but I tell you it would kill me!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because I would inevitably come to conceive love for you, because you are so talented and good, because there is such grandeur in your look. You wouldn't want this strange and torturing love; if I showed it you would find it unbecoming. And my lot would be wretched.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're a good man, but you forget the feelings of little people. We'd better keep out of your way lest you trample us. Jane Eyre adapted by Moira Buffini March 2008 112.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: St John's anger has faded. He is compassionate. This is f harder to resist.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wouldn't trample you. You'd walk at my side towards God's altar. He'd be your solace, heaven your reward. We seek to do the greatest work, to open death's gates, to save souls. Love God Jane, love God.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: St John puts his hand on her forehead; Christlike. Jane i falling under his power.

dialogues.speaker: ST JOHN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Give up your heart to Him. He is love.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane falls to her knees. St John's face is angelic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If I were sure; if I were certain -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She suddenly hears a voice: Rochester's; clear, urgent.

dialogues.speaker: ROCHESTER, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: Jane! Jane! Jane!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She springs away from St John, crying:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh God, what is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She looks wildly about the room; rushes to the window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What have you heard? What can you see?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane glances at him, seeing him for what he is; a cold, controlling man. She shouts:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am coming!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She runs out, leaving St John aghast, behind her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane runs on to the moors.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait for me!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She looks all around her at the moonlit landscape. Jane Eyre adapted by Moira Buffini March 2008 113.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The moors send her question back in an echo. We see Jane' face. Her path is clear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane is waiting for the coach at the crossroads where she arrived, almost a year before. It comes pounding towards her. She hails it. This time, the coachman respectfully descends to take her bag and help her on. She is so confident and so changed that he doesn't recognise her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane is walking through the orchard. It is wild, neglecte Its untended state worries her. She looks up. Rooks are circling, cawing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane finds herself at the side of the house. The ground i pitted with weeds. The windows are dark. She half runs round to the front. What she sees takes her breath away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The great walls and battlements are blackened with fire. Windows gape on a hollow shell. The inside of the house h collapsed. Through the hanging door, only its charred remains can be seen. Weeds grow through utter devastation Jane gazes in horror and distress.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane knocks on the door. Mrs Fairfax opens it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They sent me from the inn. I've been up at the house -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane can say no more.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come in, come in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is he dead?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs Fairfax takes Jane in her arms.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, no. Mr Rochester still lives.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane is crying tears of relief. Jane Eyre adapted by Moira Buffini March 2008 114.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell me - please -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why did you run away in the night like that? I would have helped. I would have helped.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs Fairfax has sat Jane on a settle near the fire.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He sought you as if you were a lost and precious jewel. He didn't rest. And as days turned into weeks and no word came, he grew quite savage in his disappointment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He stayed at Thornfield?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Didn't leave the house...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rochester, unshaven and unkempt is standing at his threshold.

dialogues.speaker: MRS FAIRFAX, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Shut himself up like a hermit. He only went out at night, when he walked like a ghost through the grounds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see what he is looking at: an open carriage piled with luggage, into which Mrs Fairfax is helping Adele. Leah an Sophie are already sitting inside, dressed for a journey.

dialogues.speaker: MRS FAIRFAX, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: He'd have no one near him. Adele was sent off to school. He placed me here. Only John and Martha stayed - and Mrs Poole of course.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Adele looks back at Rochester with tears in her eyes. He walks across the dark hall and slams the library doors.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rochester, in his shirt sleeves, is looking at the tree where Jane promised him her hand - now dying, cleft by lightning. The rising moon inhabits the sky. Jane Eyre adapted by Moira Buffini March 2008 115.

dialogues.speaker: MRS FAIRFAX, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: It was harvest time when it happened. No one knows how she got out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rochester hears a cry from the top floor. He sets off, a look of finality on his face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grace Poole is asleep, her empty jug of gin beside her.

dialogues.speaker: MRS FAIRFAX, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: My theory is that when Mrs Poole was asleep, having taken too much of the gin and water...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rochester takes Grace's keys.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rochester opens the door to the inner chamber.

dialogues.speaker: MRS FAIRFAX, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: ... The mad lady must have stolen her keys and let herself out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bertha Antoinetta Mason, standing in the last patch of daylight thrown down from her skylight, sees that it is Rochester. She calmly walks towards him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rochester graciously bows, indicating that she may leave. Bertha glides past him. She is free.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bertha walks past an elegant vase. She tips it to the floor. It smashes. Rochester pays it no heed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rochester has stood Bertha at his desk. A case of jewels open before her. She has put on a tiara, a diamond necklace, bracelets. She is gazing at a ruby brooch. She turns to Rochester. His expression is calm, resigned. Bertha begins to laugh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She takes the candelabra from the table. She admires herself in the mirror; her white shift, the black feather the jewels. She holds up the candelabra and sets the huge curtains alight. Jane Eyre adapted by Moira Buffini March 2008 116.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rochester is impassive; he does nothing to stop her. As s passes, Rochester realises he is bleeding. She has run th brooch pin across him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bertha knocks a lamp onto the floor. The oil springs into flames, licking the tapestries and the paintings. Rochest sees his ancestors begin to burn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The conflagration is growing. Rochester sees Bertha leavi Jane's room. As he passes, he sees everything inside it being consumed by fire. He can't bear to look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bertha is watching the rooks. Rochester goes to the edge the roof. Bertha looks at him. The invitation is clear. Rochester is ready to die.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bertha sees the rooks wheeling away. She runs at the edge of the roof. Rochester sees her intention too late. He pu out his arm to stop her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For the perfect fraction of a second, Bertha flies. Rochester sees her fall; almost falls himself - saves himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Life reawakens in him. Behind him, he sees Grace Poole, coughing, crawling up through the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Antoinetta?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Responsibility floods over him. He goes to her side, lift Grace, helps her down the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: MRS FAIRFAX, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: He didn't leave the house until everyone was out. Some say it was a just judgement on him for having her confined there all those years but for my part, I pity him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane is deeply affected.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's alive child, but many think he'd be better off dead. Jane Eyre adapted by Moira Buffini March 2008 117.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When he was taken out from under the ruins, a beam had fallen in such a way as to protect him, partly - but his eye was taken out and his left hand so crushed that he lost it. The other eye inflamed and - he is blind. He's blind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tears fall from Jane's eyes.

dialogues.speaker: MRS FAIRFAX, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I know... it's a terrible thing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I had dreaded worse. I'd dreaded he was mad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A great sense of urgency is coming over her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where is he?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane is walking through forest, along a grass grown track Her pace is fast; her journey almost at an end. She comes to a pair of rusting iron gates hanging open between granite pillars. She walks through them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She finds herself in front of a decrepit Elizabethan mano house; no garden, just a sweeping semi circle of meadow grass, which someone has cut at with a scythe. Jane stops

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Standing on the threshold is Edward Fairfax Rochester. He is in his shirtsleeves. He stands strong, stalwart, brooding. His hair is still raven black. He is looking sightlessly around his domain, with the concentration of hawk. His strength is undiminished.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He walks fifteen paces from the house. It brings him into the middle of the semicircle of grass. He is close enough for Jane to see his scarred eyes. She walks towards him, silent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A few drops of rain begin to fall. Rochester puts out his right hand to feel them. He raises his face up to the sky as if he is looking for something from there. He is absolutely still; his expression, serene.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane is very close. She steps on a twig. It breaks with a loud crack, shattering the silence. Rochester is immediately on guard, his expression turning wary. Jane Eyre adapted by Moira Buffini March 2008 118.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He suddenly swipes the air with his left arm; the ruin of it passing an inch from her face. Jane steps back. Rochester swipes again. She holds her breath.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He seems satisfied at last that nothing is there. He turn and walks fifteen paces back to the house. He disappears into the dark interior.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane starts to breathe again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane lightly taps on the side door. Martha opens it; she astonished. Jane puts her finger over her lips.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rochester is in an armchair in front of his fire. Pilot i at his feet. Jane carries in a tray with a candelabra and jug of water.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can see the candles, Martha, at your side like a luminous glow. And the fire; a red haze.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pilot notices Jane. He leaps up with a whine, wagging his tail, madly. Jane spills half the water. She cannot help finding it funny. Her entrance has been ruined by the dog

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Martha?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane giggles. Rochester's face falls.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Martha, is that you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Martha is in the kitchen, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who's there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pilot knows me. Will you have some more water? I've spilt half the glass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rochester stands, holding out his hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you are real, touch me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane touches his fingers; puts her hand in his. Rochester pulls her into his arms. Jane Eyre adapted by Moira Buffini March 2008 119.

dialogues.speaker: ROCHESTER,
dialogues.text: Her hand, her shape, her size.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And her voice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane Eyre - Jane Eyre.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My Edward, I am Jane Eyre: I have found you out. I am come back to you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For some while neither is able to speak.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're not lying dead in some ditch? Not an outcast among strangers?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've been with good people; far better than you, quite more refined and exalted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She insults me -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And I'm an independent woman. My uncle in Madeira died and left me five thousand pounds -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is real. This is practical.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm here. I'm home. I am where I love best.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane curled on Rochester's knee by the fire. He is runnin his fingers over her face, feeling its contours.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're altogether a human being, Jane?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I conscientiously believe so, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She is running her hands through his hair. Jane Eyre adapted by Moira Buffini March 2008 120.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I see that you're turning into a lion. It's time someone undertook to rehumanise you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm a sightless block -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She kisses his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And the worst of it is, I'm in danger of loving you too well for this, and making too much of you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Am I hideous, Jane?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Very. But you always were, you know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A smile cracks Rochester's face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane runs her fingers over it, feeling its contours.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He holds her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Silence falls.
